text:
These were amazing.. I did, however, change a few things.. I substituted half of the butter with softened cream cheese, and I used half splenda half regular white sugar. I used a splash more vanilla as well.. and these turned out amazing.. 

A tip.. take some parchment paper and mold your dough into a log shape, roll it up and put it in the fridge for about an hour. Then all you have to do is cut the dough into slices and place on the cookie sheet. I baked at 350 for 10 minutes.

But I have a question, do I use salted or unsalted butter, because salted butter turned our to be just fine, even more tasty blending in with the sugar. Here's a tip: Use 2 eggs, not 1. It gives the cookies a more golden look to them and it avoids the dough getting a bit too dry and crumbly, which is what happened to me.

text:
Yum! I've, strangely, never had great luck with sugar cookies but I'm out of chocolate chips and needed to make cookies for a meeting. After reading the reviews, I put the butter (in my big glass mixing bowl) in the microwave for 40 seconds to soften (it was straight out of the fridge). It was about half melted, and half very soft. I followed the recipe as stated except for doubling the vanilla. I rolled them in pink sugar crystals and baked for eight minutes and they came out perfect. Huge, huge hit. I will definitely make them again!

text:
I had a bit of trouble with the dough being crumbly, however, I did manage to roll the cookies into balls and they baked up just fine. Tip=roll out smaller balls because then you can bake them less time. Baking them a full ten minutes as I did with larger cookies causes the bottoms to become too dark because of all of the butter and sugar in them. Over all, the flavor was good...but these are really sweet...like eating pure sugar.

I had a hard time deciding how to rate this recipe.  I usually try recipes as least once as written but this time I was out of real butter and took the top reviewers suggestion of using margarine.  What I got were cookie shaped sugar biscuits.  They were still a soft cookie texture but the taste was something more like a biscuit.  I'm not sure if that's because of the margarine or because I just don't like the taste.  A quick search online did reveal that it is sometimes a bad idea to switch margarine for butter in cookie recipes.  I think today was one of those times...

text:
I have made these twice, and both times they came out perfect!  I found that softening the butter as other reviewers had suggested and using two eggs, as well as mixing on low speed has kept the batter from getting crumbly.  Cook exactly 8 minutes, and cool on sheet pan exactly 3 minutes, and you have a perfect cookie.  I found if you make them too big they won't cook all the way through, so smaller is better.

text:
My family was feening for something sweet, so I hopped online to this site in search for something that would not satisfy their sweet tooth, but also be a breeze to prepare.  I won't lie, I was drawn by the key word in the title...EASY!  LOL  This recipe was on point!  Not only was it easy and quick to prepare and bake, but it was just the right amount of sweetness.  For the softened butter, I simply nuked it in the microwave until it was soft and partially melted, and it worked lovely.  I decided to bake the cookies for 8 minutes as they came out soft and chewy; my family's preference.  The dough easily yielded 4 dozen as well, something I was pleased with.  I will DEFINITELY be adding this recipe to my rotation of sweets!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i thought these were absolutely delicious, and everyone who tried them agreed. based on reviews, i made some changes: my butter was thoroughly melted and creamed really well. i added about a half a cup of sugar to the recipe. i thought the dough was pretty stiff so i added a splash of 2% milk (i used half&half the second time, it gave it a richer flavour. also, JUST a splash- otherwise you have to add a tiny bit more flour). also, before baking them, i pressed them a tiny bit with a fork dipped in a sugar/vanilla extract mix and baked til they were almost done, then sprinkled sugar on top and baked the rest of the way. they aren't for people watching their sugar intake, but they were oh so very tasty!

text:
I made these cookies with minor changes, which is that I used an egg substitute because I don't eat eggs, vegan butter (Earth Balance "butter"), organic unbleached sugar, and I baked them on parchment paper, and I posted my picture with all the tiny cookies on a white plate with blue lines outlining it. The cookies came out awesome, they could use a little more vanilla extract maybe if you like it more sweet, but I'm making vanilla frosting for them so they came out perfect. It was my first time making cookies from scratch and I too questioned the dough as it was crumbly, but I think it came out fabulous...only 8 minutes in the oven not one second longer, and I used a teaspoon with a round bottom and then scooped and made a rounded top and balled it into my hand and you can see from the picture they came out perfect :) NOT greasy at all! I may add 1/2 a teaspoon more of extract next time if I eat them without frosting but that's all. Loved them.

text:
Delicious, simple and tasty! Maybe add a bit more vanilla extract, and this truly is the easiest, tastiest sugar cookie recipe out there. My cookies took only 6-8mins to be perfectly chewy/crispy. We then frosted some with a quick confectioner's sugar/milk icing, and my 2 year-old loved tossing sprinkles on top. We have our go-to sugar cookie recipe now! Thanks very much for sharing, Stephanie.

text:
I was looking for a quick, easy sugar cookie recipe and this seemed like a good one.  I read some of the bad reviews but thought since there were more good than bad, the recipe should turn out ok.  Oh so wrong.  I followed the recipe exactly as written, but the dough was in crumbs.  Like some other reviewers suggested, I added 1/4 c milk to try to pull it together, but it was still all crumbly.  They needed 12-15 minutes to bake and some turned out paper-thin and greasy.  If you are looking for a good, tasty, easy recipe then this isn't the one.  Keep looking.

text:
I have tried a lot of sugar cookie recipes and this one is by far the best! I was commended by all who enjoyed these delicious cookies! Once again I will reiterate what others have already said; 8 minutes is the perfect amount of time for luscious, moist, chewy on the inside/crispy on the outside cookies, two teaspoons of vanilla extract definitely gives it a little more of a kick, and making sure the butter is extremely soft helps as well. Upon coming across this recipe and reading the reviews I was more than excited to give them a try, I am very glad I did. I recommend this recipe to all who enjoy the perfect sugar cookie!

text:
The first time I tried this recipe, they surprisingly came out pretty well. The cookies were kind of small, but also had a nice thickness to them , as well as softness. I also used margarine instead of the butter. Once all combined, the dough was very hard to work with, but it turned out just right, and was easy to roll into small little balls as the recipe calls for.   I have on clue what happened from then on. I've tried this recipe quite a few times since, and it WILL NOT work. This is the most annoying recipe I've ever witnessed. It's like if you don't do everything exactly right, you are totally screwed. Today I was attempting to make them to give as holiday gifts, and they are going all flat on me, and don't have the same consistency or anything. I did chill them over night so maybe that was a BAD idea. I was just trying to save time. Last time I had to cook these cookies like 12 min, and now I can't seem to figure out how long the cook. They either come out too soft and not cooked, or too crispy. Plus, it has too much of a buttery taste going on.   Now, I have to figure out something else to cook for Christmas, instead of these.

text:
I LOVE these sugar cookies.  I added a little more vanilla than called for, but I always do that.  I read through some comments and saw that some were a disappointment.  I used real butter.  If you use margarine they won't come out well.  Mine were rather soft -- which I liked.  Also, if you compare to store bought--well, there is no comparison.  Store bought usually adds lots of sugar to make up for vanilla, and probably don't use real butter.  These aren't yukky sweet at all.  Full of flavor.  5 stars for sure.

text:
These aren't the best sugar cookies I've ever had, but they are the best EASY sugar cookies I've made.  I only made one change the the recipe - I added more vanilla - 2 tsp instead of one.  It is very important to use softened butter (never margarine!) and cream the sugars till light and fluffy.  I used a cookie scoop and rolled the balls in sugar.  I baked for 8 minutes on airbake cookie sheets. They turned out perfect and they disappeared quickly! Yum!

text:
My dough came out a little crumbly as other reviewers mentioned.  I just pressed it all together and wrapped it in saran wrap in the fridge.  Then I scooped it out and rolled half in red sugar crystals and the other half in green sugar crystals.  They came out perfect!  Crispy on the edges and soft and chewy middles.  YUM!  Next time I will make sure to cream the butter better as other reviewers mentioned.  Wish I had read the reviews first, LOL  But either way, these cookies were great!

userID:
2623074
Display Name:
Trixie
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
50
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an easy recipe to prepare.  I rolled it so that the kids could cut out cookies, and it worked pretty well.  I halved the recipe (lightly beat 1 egg then use 1 1/2 tbsp of it, to get half an egg), but still used 1 tsp vanilla, which was perfect.  Both kids got to cut out 8 medium to large cookies.  Then we decorated them with sprinkles, baked and enjoyed.  Usually making sugar cookies is an ordeal - more dough than they have attention span for, and frosting which makes it all more complicated.  This way kept it simple and the recipe was still sweet enough without frosting for the kids to enjoy.  When the portion that I'd put in the refrigerator for an hour or so came out rock hard I microwaved it on a very low power level for less than 30 seconds and it went back to its original consistency.  I realized after the first batch that since the cookies are thinner rolled I needed to shorten the baking time to somewhere between 6-7 minutes.  The remaining scraps of dough I mushed together into tbsp-sized drops and made 1/2 tsp-sized divots which I filled with jam - also very tasty!
Review:

These were a fantastic base sugar cookie--I did add a tablespoon of skim milk because the dough was dry and wouldn't stick together and I also added a half teaspoon of salt for good measure, but these come out great on their own or embellished.  I made half of them plain and on the other half, I rolled the dough in sugar, then I halved some milky way and 3 musketeer minis and pressed them cut side down into the top of the cookies when they were hot out of the oven. text:
This is by far the best sugar cookie recipe I've used and all of my friends love it.  I add a dash of cinnamon and a half teaspoon more of the vanilla extract to the mix, and make a mixture of cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, and sugar to sprinkle on top as the cookies cool for a delicious snickerdoodle version.  Or my dad likes it when I add a teaspoon of freshly grated orange peel to the mix and just sprinkle with regular sugar as they cool.  Both variations are delicious.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's a good starter recipe if you don't know how to make sugar cookies. In terms of prepping, it doesn't create a big mess like other recipes do. Just use a good wire whisk and a sturdy bowl and you're good to go.   The taste might be a bit lackluster if you want it plain. I'd suggest adding some topping to this like M&M's, candy, or chocolate chips to give it more flavor.  Otherwise, I'd highly recommend this for people who don't want a big mess or a confusing recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This afternoon I wanted something sweet and easy with just a few ingredients that I knew I had in my pantry.  A quick search for "easy sugar cookie" brought me to this recipe.  This was SO quick and easy!  These look and taste just like the sugar cookies from the bakery!!  I did make one deviation from the recipe.  I was out of eggs, so I used a 1/4 cup of vanilla soymilk in place of the egg.  Also -- I used salted butter (the recipe didn't specify).  The cookies turned out beautiful!  Perfectly buttery and sweet.

          Edited 10/08 -- I just made these again, and they weren't nearly as good.  I'm not sure where I went wrong exactly, but this time the cookies were hard and barely spread at all.  Also - this time I used unsalted butter, and the cookies were really bland.  I wholeheartedly recommend using salted butter for these!

text:
This is a nice cookie, I dont always have the time to roll out and decorate cookies, with this cookie you dont need to. I did dip them in sugar before baking, its really a no-fail recipe as long as you measure everything properly.
I wanted to add just a tip, I knew there was going to be too much flour by reading the recipe so I omitted a 1/4 of a cup. The butter was the right amount, and before baking the WHOLE batch you really shoud bake 2 or 3 first to see how they are before ruining an entire batch.

text:
Just baked the "half version" to only end up with 2 dozen (plenty!)  Definitely make sure that the butter is room temperature.  If you like really soft cookies like I do, only bake for 7 minutes...my first dozen I baked for 8 (at just over 350) and they were crispy - flavorful - but crispy.  I also took the advice of another member and doubled the vanilla, and they have a wonderful flavor!!  Overall, a very tasty and simple recipe that I will bake again!!

text:
I just made a batch of these. I had no vanilla, so I added cinnamon and nutmeg instead, and a pinch of salt. After taking them out of the oven, I dusted them with powdered sugar.  These are the most amazing sugar cookies I've ever tasted. That are amazing. Crisp on the outside, soft and chewy on the inside.  I think it's important to not overmix the dough when you add the dry ingredients. Stir until just mixed. My batter was like breadcrumbs, I put a little on the palm of my hand then placed the other hand over and rolled until it became a ball.

text:
I cooked these exactly as the recipe says and I had a bit of a problem - they didn't spread out very nicely at all. They stayed mostly in the (very small) round shape, which made for cookies that were dry on the outside and too wet in the middle. The taste was pretty good, but I wouldn't serve them to guests. I guess if I made them again, I would make them tablespoon-sized balls instead of teaspoon sized balls and I would pat them down flatter before putting them in the oven.

text:
These are very tasty and are in fact very easy to make. I do like that they are not as sweet as most sugar cookies, however, I only gave this recipe 3 stars because the batter was fairly hard to work with. It just didn't seem to have enough liquid so the dough was very dry. I found it very hard to roll the dough into balls because it kept crumbling in my hands. My daughter wanted to use her cookie cutters and it was also hard to roll out and transfer her shapes to the pan without it crumbling. I added another 1/2 cup of butter which helped and also reduced cooking time to 7 minutes as my oven is fan assisted.

text:
I just made these for the kids to decorate and I think these are really good!! The dough can be a bit crumbly so it is best to refrigerate and spray your hands with a little Pam when shaping. I pressed these down just a little with my palms and sprinkled with sugar before baking. DO NOT OVER BAKE, especially if you like a chewy cookie. When you see a slight golden tinge around the edge they are done. GREAT recipe and thank you for sharing.

text:
I followed another reviewer's advice and made sure the butter was very soft (but not melted).  The other review said that this made the cookies very soft and buttery.  This was not my experience.  I followed the recipe and found that it was extremely crumbly and would not hold together.  I added an extra egg and two more teaspoons of vanilla (one tablespoon total).  With the additional ingredients dough held together perfectly.  The dough did not spread very much  when it baked but were a perfect golden brown after eight minutes.  After they cooled they looked exactly like the picture and are very buttery and soft.

text:
thx for this easy recipe. all though its quite good i've added my own twist to it. like ranger cookies i've added several ingredients to it, coconut 1 cup an extra egg, add half white sugar and half brown sugar,1/2 to 1 cup of oats, pecans or walnuts,if dough is to stiff add some butter-but usually its just right. add an extra teaspoon of vanilla, also my son loves chocolate chips added to them, i always use self rising flour and no baking soda or salt or baking powder. make cookies into about a rounded teaspoon full of dough or they puff way up, and these cookies stay softer for days

text:
I gave up on making sugar cookies many years ago after never being able to recreate the delicious cookies I found in the grocery store.  This weekend we were snowed in and my husband and I really wanted sugar cookies, so I thought I'd give it another try with this recipe.  I could not have imagined that they would turn out so well! We both agreed these are better than our favorite grocery store cookies.  I used two tsp of vanilla as several reviewers have suggested. I also used real butter and had no problems with consistency.  The directions say to use a heaping tsp, but I used a heaping tablespoon and the cookies came out a very normal size.  I will be using this recipe again very soon!

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4414518
Display Name:
Shadagee
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been looking for this recipe for months, it's pretty darned close to my mom's which I lost a few years back.  These were our Christmas cookies, and after baking them I"m not sure it's the same.    Have a few suggestions to tweak it - make sure you sift the flour, and sift the rest of the dry ingredients (except the sugar) into it. remeasure after you sift. Eliminate the baking soda, increase the baking powder to 1 teaspoon. This keeps them from coming out like rocks.  Make the vanilla 1 tablespoon, and add a half teaspoon of salt.  refrigerate the dough before you roll and cut it.  I used a metal rolling pin.     sprinkle flour over your counter, and on top of the dough to keep the rolling pin from sticking.   Do not use the non-stick cookie sheets, they will burn. Air bake is much better.   I also add a simple butter frosting to this - stick of softened butter, confectioners sugar and milk.  I just keep adding sugar, then a little milk until I get the consistancy right.  Decorated with colored sugars, or use food coloring to tint it.    Yes it's a cholesterol nightmare, but they are SO good.  They freeze reasonably well, although I'd recommend not freezing with the frosting already on.    The original recipe also called for grated lemon zest and cream of tartar.  We never used them.

5

This recipe perfectly lived up to it's name.  It was simple to make and they tasted delicious.  I took the advice of the reviewer that recommended that the butter should be COMPLETELY softened before creaming.  I think that was key to making tasty cookies.  I would also recommend that you make sure that the middle is done.  The first batch that I made was taken out of the oven too early because I was trying to hard to keep them from getting hard.

text:
A good basic recipe, though I modified it a bit after reading the reviews.  Instead of 2 3/4 cup flour I used 1 3/4 cup and i used 1.5 tsp vanilla extract.  Oven time was approx. 8-9 minutes.  I also used tablespoons instead of teaspoon fulls so I would have larger cookies.  We decorated with sprinkles, colored sugar and M&Ms and they came out wonderful!

country:

text:
This is by far the BEST sugar cookie recipe I have ever came across! It makes the perfect soft, buttery cookie you have ever tasted! They came out PERFECT when cooked, in a gas oven, for 8 minutes. The dough was so easy, my 8 year old son did everything but the measuring! He had a blast rolling the dough into balls. It was great because the dough doesn't have to be chilled. I am a HUGE fan of Subway's sugar cookies and this recipe is the closest I have ever came, to comparing it, to theirs. For christmas, I believe we will bake a few more batches and roll them in holiday colored sugars for Santa to enjoy on Christmas Eve ;) I highly recommend trying this recipe. Follow the steps just like it calls for and they will turn out perfect!

text:
These cookies are so simple and delicious! I didn't have time to wait for the butter to soften all the way, so I just nuked it in the microwave for ten seconds and it was soft, but still solid.  I had to bake mine an average of 9-10 minutes, and they came out crispy on the outside, soft on the inside- just the way I like them! I have a feeling my housemates will be pleased when they wake up in the morning =)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can't much judge these cookies themselves because I always add things to them, but I can recommend wonderful additions! Last time I made these, I substituted apple sauce for the egg (about 1/3 cup) although egg can be used, too. Additionally, I sprinkled ground cinnamon into the dough (to taste) and also added three packets of Quaker Instant Oatmeal Cinnamon Apple. This gives it a nostalgic, sweet autumn taste. The applesauce, however, often results in a cakey texture which often ends up better the next day. That's great with a glass of milk (or soy milk - the sweetness of soy milk is great with these cookies). The only difficult thing was trying to figure out how to describe them to people... "Apple Cinnamon-Sugar Oatmeal Cookies"?

text:
WOW!!!  These cookies were the BEST!!!!  They were SO chewy and yummy!  We used margarine instead of butter, added a 1/2 tsp of extra baking powder, and 1/2 cup of extra flour.  The kids and I rolled them in some colored sugar before putting them in the oven...baked them on a stone (which I swear by for good chewy cookies) for about 10 minutes...Mmmmm!!  Delicious!   I have been looking for a no fuss sugar cookie for years...but none of them turned out very well. This recipe is definitely a keeper...it was SO simple...we had great tasting sugar cookies in no time!!!!  THANKS!!!!

OMG! These are the best sugar cookies ever. I didn't cook them longer than 10 minutes, so they were light and chewy. One batch was in for about 12 minutes and when cooled they were a little crunchy. I prefer chewy, so between 8-10 minutes is best. Otherwise, I made no changes to the recipe. I wish there was a lock on the cookie jar because my family has eaten almost all of them already (myself included)! I will keep this recipe forever, and I will never buy a sugar cookie from Pillbury, Nestle, or a cookie bakery again... These are better!

text:
Well I thought this recipe was ok, but not the best! It says don't grease the pan, GREASE IT! Also instead of using butter, I used margarine. Also Cook a little longer than it says, for about 15 minutes for the perfect soft cookies. Only put about 6 cookies on a tray, because they get really big. about 3 inches wide. Also they taste alot better if you sprinkle a little sugar on top of them. Follow these directions, and you'll get better cookies!! trust me!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/209766.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been on the search for the best sugar cookies which don't require rolling out and these are it!  They are even better than the sugar cookies  my grandma used to make--more buttery and they rose beautifully where the ones my grandma made, although still good, were drier and flater.  It can be hard to tell when these cookies are done, but I followed the reviewer Amy Yvonne's tip to take out the cookies when the tops are just starting to crack.  Then I let them sit on the cookie sheet for a few minutes before putting on the wire racks. They turned out great--soft but chewy.  They are not too sweet, so I rolled them in raw turbinado sugar before baking them to give them some more sweetness and texture.

text:
This is truly an honest buttery-tasting cookie which goes together quickly and nicely.  I have made this recipe five times in the past month, and everyone raves about it.  I like to decorate with a shimmering sanding sugar or a colored sugar.  I normally prefer a softer cookie; however, this one, although crisp, melts in your mouth with a delicious buttery flavor.  As suggested, I use 2 teaspoons of vanilla. Otherwise, do not alter this recipe. Also, do not use unsalted butter in this recipe.  I strongly recommend this as a cookie  to "always have on hand" since it appeals to people of all ages.

text:
I suspect this recipe could be improved by balancing ingredients for a more supple batter, but my quick fix for crumbling batter is simply working it by hand after all the dry ingredients have been added.  The heat introduced by folding and shaping by hand is enough to soften the batter.  Also added extra vanilla extract as other reviewers have done, as well as 1/2 tsp orange extract for zest.

I must be doing something wrong, with all the 5 star ratings for these. Even though I used room temperature Butter Flavored Crisco, these cookie were CRUMMY! I increased the vanilla to 1.5 teaspoons. I added a second egg to the remaining dough and with the second batch in the oven, they didn't quite get done, broke apart semi baked. I am disappointed. They did puff a bit, which was nice.

text:
These were amazing cookies!! Not only were they convenient to make (no chilling), everything about them was perfect. They were soft and delicious. Just a few notes: I added an additional tsp of vanilla. On half of the batches I made I dipped the cookies in sugar before putting them in the oven. The sugar made them crispier on the outside, but the softness within was unchanged. Also, for maximum softness, serve straight out of the oven. These cookies cold are rather hard...

text:
Excellent cookies! Everyone loved them and they were easy to make. 1) Make sure to the following: Use around 1 1/2-2 tsps vanilla extract instead of 1. 2) Use butter COMPLETELY at room temperature. 3) Bake only 8 minutes. 4) Space cookies farther apart because these expand alot. 5) Make sure to use fresh baking soda or else your cookies will fall flat.

text:
I would have to say this is a really good recipe... however I altered mine. I increased my flour to 3 1/4 cups.  Vanilla to 2 1/2 tsp.  I also melted my butter just to the point where it was starting to get runny.  I mixed the sugar, baking powder, soda, and vanilla with the butter and slowly whipped in my flour... Baked at 375.. I did once batch at 7 mins and one at 8 mins.  Both are extremely tender and chewy even after cooling... the 8 min one just has a crunchier outside.

text:
I made these as per Rolanda's tip and made sure that the butter was soft and then creamed the butter and sugar together very well. They turned out great - crispy outside and chewy inside! The only thing was that I had to be careful of the baking time. I found that 7 or 8 min was plenty and any longer made them too hard and brown. It could be just the way my oven is though. I added a pink M&M to the centre of each cookie while they were soft because they were for a friend's daughter's birthday party. Everyone loved them!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very easy!
...but for us, not so "quick"
Took us 2 hours.
But that's probably because we were having too much fun shaping the cookies.
ahem.
Well, we used organic sugar. I might use less next time, as it was a little too sweet! And sometimes the dough was crumbly, and hard to shape into balls (we used our hands). It's a pretty dry dough. I wasn't sure whether to put water in it or not...in the end, we didn't, and they turned out fine! Also, it's better to leave it in the oven longer, since it doesn't finish baking very quickly!

I had fun with this recipe with my friends, it's worth trying :)

PS: don't put very thick chunks of dough into the oven, or they won't turn out very well :D

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
These are delicate and delightful! I've made them as written and they are tasty, but I prefer to leave out the vanilla and use two teaspoons of almond extract instead. Gorgeous. 

Also, for others like me who prefer to dirty only one bowl: It works perfectly well to mix the wet ingredients first, then pile the dry ingredients on top. You can gently stir the baking powder and baking soda into the flour with a fork -- then fold  all of the ingredients together. You may want to knead the dough with your hands as it's rather flaky and a little hard to mix with a spatula/spoon/etc. Bakes up lovely, though!

text:
I always find it funny how one recipe could have two totally different outcomes.  When I read reviews for this recipe, I read some say it's crumbly so it's hard to work with and some others said it was too sticky to work with.  I didn't know which ones to believe until I made my own.  I thought the batter was perfect to work with (keep in mind I didn't use cookie cutters) just making round cookies.  It was chewy on the inside and crunchy on the outside, PERFECT!  However, I did use "I cannot believe it's not butter spread instead of real butter and doubled the vanilla.  I did put frosting on them and placed one bunny marshmallow on top for Easter.  This is the best sugar cookie I ever tasted and I sure will make them again!  Thank you!

text:
This recipe is the easiest "from scratch" recipe I've ever made! It really wowed my husband and friends. And it makes enough cookies for an army! They are delicious, and I have to admit, I'm not a very good cook. So -- I have to recommend it to everyone. Especially if you are a broke college student! I didn't have any baking powder or baking soda, so I had to leave that out, but the cookies were still way better then anything you can buy at the store. When I took them out of the oven, I melted a little butter on the tops and sprinkled them with sugar. Delish!!!

text:
These were certainly easy!  My kids wanted to make cookies and we didn't have a lot of time... so we made these.  I just sort of fashioned them into flattened circles and let the kids decorate them.  Then while we ate lunch I cooked and cooled the first batch and stuck the rest of the dough in the fridge.  I rolled them out afterwards, and it went OK -- the dough was easy to roll and cut, but they definitely spread while cooking, so this isn't the recipe for intricate cutouts.  

I actually followed the recipe exactly (I never do that!) and was pleased.  Tasty, easy to make, easy to work with, easy to clean up after.  Not the best cookie ever, but a versatile kid-friendly and easy recipe.  :)

text:
I made these last week to share with the playgroup kids for Valentine's Day. The only change I made was to add an extra 1/2 tsp of vanilla, but I'm still rating it 5 stars, because I think this is more of a personal preference issue. I rolled mine in red sugar sprinkles before baking, and then pressed a cherry juju heart into each of them after they came out of the oven. Everyone, kids and moms, loved them. I got lots of compliments, and the cookies were almost gone by the time playgroup was over. I was happy there were a few left so my 7 year old could have a couple when he got home from school. I'm definitely keeping this recipe, and am making again tonight so I can share them with the preschool kids tomorrow.

text:
This recipe provided very yummy results!

I used an electric mixer to cut butter and sugar together; rolled dough into balls that I flattened with a glass bottom dipped in color sugar; baked the cookies for 7 minutes and cooled them on the cookie sheet for 1 minute before moving to a wire rack.

My family likes cookies to be crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside, and these were perfect. Still chewy inside after a couple of days.

I'm going to make this recipe again, but this time I'll try rolling the balls in cinnamon-sugar and not flattening them.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are unbelievable! After my last few attempts in which the dough came out too dry, I made the following changes and they came out FANTASTIC: I reduced the flour to 2½ cups (loosley measured; don't pack it), ½ tsp. of baking soda and baking powder. I doubled the vanilla to 2 tsps. for greater depth of taste. I was worried that the cookies wouldn't rise properly with the baking soda and powder reductions, but this was not a problem. They came out beautifully. Leave in for 8 minutes for chewy cookies and 10 if you like them crisper around the edges. I also made some of them with a single marchiano cherry on top (cut in half), in the middle. :-) Delish!

text:
I scaled this recipe to 98..I had to use shortning instead of margarine or butter, also, I had no vanilla!
But I tried anyway - the mixture came out extremely dry and I almost gave up. But first I ended up adding 2 more eggs, about one and a half more shortning, and give or take around half c. more of sugar. Rolled in colored sugar, and crossed my fingers...the results were amazing, I can't belive how good they came out. Soft and a little chewy, not falling apart- just right. In fact this might be my new favorite!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Taste was good on these. We made Moon Pies out of 1/2 and snickerdoodles out of 1/2. Yeah, I've got a pretty big sweet tooth. :)
Be REALLY CAREFUL not to overbake because on my first batch, I left them in 9 minutes because they didn't look done to me.. big mistake! They were fine until they cooled about 3 minutes.. then they spread all over the place and got way too crispy. It was weird.
Anyway, just take them out at 8 minutes, and trust me, they won't look done. Just do it! They'll be nice and chewy and round that way. Thanks for the recipe!

These cookies were absolutely what I was looking for. Just the right texture & taste. The outside edges were crispy, while the middle was soft & warm. I do recommend putting the dough in the refridgerator for about 5-10 minutes before you handle the dough. I also had to change the cooking time. It took me 10-12 minutes to cook mine. Overall, these cookies were exactly what I was looking for! :)

text:
Easy and tasty! I added a bit more vanilla than the recipe called for and they came out great at 375 for 10 minutes. I tried leaving them in for 8 minutes, as suggested by some reviewers, and they were still doughy in the middle. Just make sure you keep an eye on them is all I can really offer! ***UPDATE*** Decided to make these again and they came out great. Prior to baking I rolled mine in a combo of 2 tbsp. sugar to 1 tsp. cinnamon and they came out awesome. Definitely a keeper recipe now.

userID:
662701
Display Name:
Misty
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
11
favoritesCount:
47
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the first sugar cookie recipe I've found that I actually like.  As per other reviews, they are perfect--sweet & buttery but not overly rich, crisp around the edges & chewy in the middle.  Yum.

My only complaint is that they tasted a bit eggy for my liking, but I added the zest of a couple of limes after baking the first pan & they're absolutely gorgeous.  No doubt lemon zest would work equally well, but I love the combination of lime and vanilla.

Also, the cookie dough can come up a bit sticky, but there's no need to chill the dough before rolling it into balls.  Just put a couple tablespoons of flour into a deep plate and dip your fingertips (dusting off the excess) before shaping the dough.  It only takes a tiny bit of flour to stop the dough sticking to your hands, and I find that this works like a charm.

Oh, and I rolled the balls of dough in vanilla demerara sugar to give them a bit of crunch.  Perfect.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe and so versatile too... Instead of vanilla extract I used almond extract and added 1 1/2 T of poppy seeds just to try something a little different.  Compliments iced tea and fruit really well.  Also after reading the reviews, I adjusted the recipe by reducing the sugar by 1/4 cup, reducing the baking soda by 1/4 tsp and adding a 1/2 tsp of salt. (I used unsalted butter.)  The cookies did spread some while baking, but I had 12 on a 15.5x20 insulated cookie sheet and they didn't touch.  Will definitely make again.

This is by far the best sugar cookie recipe I've come across. The key to keeping them soft and not crumbly is the cooking time. The cookies do not need to be even lightly brown when you pull them out, check the bottoms only. If pulled early enough they stay moist and soft!

EXCELLENT cookies and so easy...no rolling and cutting (although you could if you needed to). I added 1/4 tsp salt like a reviewer recommended.  I used a small cookie scooper that has a lever to drop the dough onto the cookie sheet so my cookies were perfectly round.  I bake them the full 10 minutes...8 minutes made them too doughy (depends on your altitude)  After they cooled my daughter decorated them for Christmas give-aways.  We made six batches of these delicious cookies!

text:
This recipe is perfect- easy, foolproof, and delicious!  Slightly crispy on the outside but yumyumYUM chewy on the inside.  Make sure you refrigerate the dough first because it is very sticky!! I Replaced 1/2c of white sugar w/ confectioner's sugar as suggested.  I wanted to make a colorful plate of assorted sugar cookies, so I doubled the recipe and set up 6 different plates w/ different sugars to roll the cookies in prior to baking: red sugar, blue sugar, cinnamon sugar, brown sugar, white sugar, and chopped nuts... baked about a third of them without any sugar and decorated those with melted white and milk chocolate.  This was the best looking (and tasting) tray of sugar cookies that I've ever seen!

text:
This recipe is absolutely amazing!!!!  Every christmas I make sugar cookies with crushed candy canes on top and the original recipe called for the premade frozen sugar cookie dough.  I have been searching for a sugar cookie recipe that I can make from scratch to use instead.  The problem is that most sugar cookie repices i have found are incredibly difficult or time consuming, so its easire to just use the premade dough.  This recipe is super easy to make and tastes much better than the generic premade dough.  
If you are interested in the candy cane cookies, simply crush the candy canes (I use a hammer and a plastic bag) and sprinkle them on top of sugar cookie dough before baking.  They are a real winner at holiday parties!!!!

text:
Great, easy recipe. I roll the dough into small balls. I then take a drinking glass, dip the bottom of the glass into granulated sugar to keep the dough from sticking, and press the dough balls out into very thin perfectly round shapes. They cook quickly and are a great almost Moravian-style cookie. My friends love the crispiness. You can use colored sugar with the glass for a seasonal color accent.

text:
Great recipe!!  Reviewed many of the sugar cookie recipes on this site--looking for an easy no-roll version and choose this one as most seemed to have success with it!  I upped the vanilla to 1 1/2 tsp and changed sugar to 1c white 1/2c confectioners as some had suggested.  Made these with my 4 yr old so had to roll in colored sugar or sprinkes or cinnamon & sugar-- looked great--  tasted terrific-- would keep baking time to 8 min to keep soft.  Excellent-- quick to make as cookies don't spread too much so you can fit many on a single pan-- will make again soon!

text:
My mommy left me home alone because she took my sissy shoe shopping, so I made cookies all by myself because I wanted candy.  I was going to use Vanilla, but I used lemon juice instead because I read the bottle and it said "contains alcohol" and this is red ribbon week and I know drugs are bad.  Anyway, my cookies came out the right way (crispy outside, chew inside) but when my mom and sister tasted them and said they were crispy, which made me kind of sad because I wanted chewy ones.  Also, I put in powdered sugar because I read some other lady's recipe and hers had powdered sugar in it and I thought that would make it yummier, so maybe it did.  I also put frosting on these because the cookies from the store have frosting and theirs are really squishy and yummy and I steal them all the time from the free cookie plate, but these didn't taste like them, so I guess that was bad.
My sissy and mom just came home now and ate the cookies, here is their review "yeah, these are ok, but Sarah is a super cook." and "I give these cookies a 5, but I'd probably give any cookie a 5."  kthxbye

text:
I thought these were very good! I am not a big fan of sugar cookies, but I enjoyed these. These were just the perfect consistancy-not too soft or too crunchy! I liked them also because they weren't overly sweet even though I rolled them in white sugar  before I baked them. I liked the fact that I didn't have to place them in the fridge to chill also.  Delicious!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies were really delicious.  We wanted to use cookie cutters so we followed another reviewer's advice by adding 1/4 cup more flour.  The dough was still too sticky when I rolled it so I just added more flour as I went.  The cookies turned out a little hard, so either the 8 minutes is too long or the 375 is too hot, but once I adjusted it, they turned out fine.  The cookies are a little bland, which is great if you add a frosting on top.  Overall very good recipe and my 5 year old loved them!

text:
This recipe is a really good one! Easy is definitely what I'd call it. I used it to make cut-out Christmas cookies, but it did spread a bit too much. I'd recommend adding 1/4 to 1/2 cup more flour to help the cookies keep their shape (or you could cut down a little on the butter). Also, I added about a teaspoon of lemon flavor just because I like a lemony hint in my sugar cookies. This one's a keeper!

text:
Really good but don't use too much dough in each cookie or else it won't completely bake. If you want really big cookies then you can use more than a teaspoon of dough, just remember to push it down with a fork or something. I recommend adding lemon juice or more vanilla to get more flavor if you are not using frosting.

They were so good! One thing that always gets my baking in trouble is how much I melt my butter... I made these twice. The first time I melted my butter perfectly, not too much, not too little, and they were soft inside but crunchy at the same time. And they were rounded, not flat. But the second time I struggled with my butter and melted it too much so they came out very flat and more crunchy than soft.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2669155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe! I changed it for chocolate chip cookies too. Here is the one I use (without chips for sugar) Here is the recipe:
2 3/4 cups flour (1 cup was oat flour)
1/2 tsp baking powder
1tsp baking soda
1 pinch salt
1/4 tsp cinnamon
1/2 cup softened butter
1/2 cup oil
1 cup white sugar
1/2 cup brown sugar
1tsp vanilla
1 egg
1 1/2 to 2 cups chocolate chips
375 degree oven bake 8- 10 min. 
Mix dry ingredients. Cream butter, oil, sugars and egg. Combine wet with dry. Chill dough better results . Have fun!

Made the recipe exactly as written.
This year I was asked to bring ‘the best sugar cookies ever, the ones I brought for Christmas two years ago’ I couldn’t remember which recipe I used so I made four different versions of sugar cookies and we had a taste-off. I brought these, one with a small amount of sour cream, one with a full cup of sour cream(makes a nice fluffy cookie),  and one with 8 oz of cream cheese (makes a rolled sugar cookie). By far people preferred this cookie.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6244053.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this with my 5 & 12 year olds. I doubled the amount of vanilla extract that the recipe calls for.  The dough was easy to work with, a little sticky.  Because doing it with kids, the cookies were a little big and not uniform in size, thus they ran together while baking.  I also cooked them for 12 minutes since they were so big and thick. Once I took them out of the oven, I let them cool for 2 minutes then used a pizza cutter to gently cut them apart, as you can see, not the best shapes. We plan to decorate them with icing and sprinkles once they cool. I will say they are not very sweet though, hopefully the icing and sprinkles will fix that.  I do plan to try this again, and maybe use a little more sugar than the recipe calls for to make them a tad sweeter.

text:
Easy & delicious.  I cut the recipe in half and got  2 dozen cookies.   Do NOT cook until golden brown....cook only until the edges begin to turn brown for soft cookies.   I believe that may be the reason some have reported them being dry.  I also sprinkled with sugar when done...that makes a big difference, as well.

These were so good.  I didn't make any changes, made the recipe as described.  These were delicious, the texture was perfect.  I have tried other sugar cookie recipes before with little success but I am saving this one!  I'm not a big cookie baker but these inspired me to start a Christmas tradition. I was short on time, though, and just went for it with somewhat cold butter.  Even then, they turned out great.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am unsure if this was a repeat recipe. I added the extra teaspoon of vanilla and after reading others reviews stating it needed something did about half a teaspoon of almond extract. I allowed the butter to completely soften per another review but when I finished adding all the dry ingredients it was still very tacky. I just received a kitchenaid stand mixer and really wanted to give it a shot this recipe was easy enough so I chose it. If you want to roll the dough out to cut shapes you may want to use another recipe. When all the ingredients were mixed up the dough was very tacky I added 1/4 cup flour and mixed it up again I thought that would be enough but it wasn't, I dumped it on my heavily floured counter and added more flour to end the tackiness. By the time I put the last batch on the sheet I had added at least 1 1/2 - 2 additional cups of flour and kneaded it in. This is also a drop cookie style recipe the last batch I rolled then smashed and it looks better. They do taste great though, the dough before baking is silky soft, after baking they are very light, I might be able to eat a dozen myself they are so light. I am unsure I will try this recipe again usually when I make cookies its for work or to bake with my grandangels. The girls want to do shaped cookies so this recipe wouldn't be good for that.

None
text:
I love this recipe. It's super simple to make and it turns out perfect. A lot of people are saying that their dough is too dry/crumbly and I think I know what happened because I had that problem too. I mistakenly thought that one stick of butter was equal to one cup. IT IS NOT! Follow the directions and it will never turn out dry. 

This is also an easy recipe to manipulate too. I've added an extra teaspoon of vanilla extract for more flavorful cookies. I've rolled them around in cinnamon sugar before baking. And my favorite so far is adding about two tablespoons of lemon extract. The possibilities are endless.

text:
I made it but even my large egg wasn’t enough moisture for dry dough so I used two large eggs.  This dough can be rolled in white sugar before popping them on a cookie sheet.  They needed the full time in my oven but with them rolled in sugar, they cake out light and slightly fluffy.  As delicious if not better than any bakery cookie! 
Try this recipe but use that extra egg otherwise your dough will be sandy and not dough like.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies just won a cookie contest and saved my butt.

I spent the afternoon making elaborate, overly-ambitious cookies for my friends' informal (but highly competitive) holiday cookie contest. Honestly, they were just not very good. So, with an hour before the party, I used this recipe to make salted caramel thumbprint cookies with leftover homemade caramel from the failed cookies. I had to put them in the freezer to cool in time, but they were delicious and won "Best Overall" cookie.

I agree with the comments that the butter needs to be SOFT. When my dough was crumbly, I put it in the microwave for 10-15 seconds at a time, which helped. The baked cookies were a little dry, but the texture paired very well with the soft caramel.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made these several times.  They are never around long long enough for me to ice- all eaten by the second day.
Two things:  Make sure the oven temperature is correct-use an oven thermometer. 
Also, do not over cook.  They will be brittle.  The cook time depends  upon the temperature of the uncooked dough when placed in the oven. Depending on the dough temperature,  cook time varies from 10 to 12 minutes.  Also, allow to cool for several minutes before moving to wire rack.  This recipe is fast and easy.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7284982.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
At long last, an internet recipe that completely lived up to its hype. Fortunately, I read through the reviews and gleaned some helpful tips:
1. Double the specified amount of vanilla.
2. Use margarine instead of butter
3. If you want a soft cookie, wait until the edges begin to turn golden and remove them from the oven.
4. When creaming the margarine/sugar mix, do it until you figure it's completely blended...then do it a little bit more. Do the same when sifting the dry mix ingredients together and likewise when combining all ingredients. It really makes a difference.

I made one inch dough balls and then tapped them down on the cookie sheet with my thumb until I had uniform, 3/8" thick discs with a slightly concave (hollowed) top. I sprinkled and pressed coarse colored sugar crystals into the tops with a spoon. I ended up with beautiful, dome-shaped 2" cookies.

Its a good taste. The problem with this recipe is its touted as good for cut cookie shapes. It is not. The cookie dough spreads a ridiculous amount in the oven. Omit the baking powder to stop this problem from occuring. I should have realized this would happen as self rising flour is made with baking powder. Now i have a bunch of dough that i cant use for pretty cut shapes. I guess I'll have to do circles or drop cookies.

I followed another user’s suggestion to increase the vanilla, make sure my butter was super soft and To only bake for 8-9 minutes. I thought they would be underdone but as they cooled, the edges became delightfully crispy while the rest of the cookie remained nice and chewy. I really loved the simplicity of this recipe. I didn’t feel like dragging out the mixer so I mixed by hand(well I had my husband do it haha) and they came out perfect. Thank you and we can’t wait to make these when the kids are actually awake!

I love this recipe... So very easy... Now I was a tad bit concern with mixing the butter and sugar together..
 That being because it never got smooth instead it should say mix until it fluffs... me personally I beat my butter first until it creamed and then added the sugar and mixed until it fluffed... Besides that the only other thing I did was what I seen someone else mention and that was add more vanilla I actually just added ¼ tsp more... Overall this recipe was a success and I will use over and over again... I love that you don't have to chill... Best part about it

userID:
26171285
Display Name:
Michele Dickinson
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7069573.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Will be making these again! Everyone in my VERY picky family loved them, & there was plenty of cookies to go around. Ended up splitting one batch of batter into 2 (one regular, one snickerdoodle). 

Regular sugar cookies came out perfect. Snicker doodles, expanded more, but were still good.  Grand cookie count was: 50.  1 Tsp sized dollop makes the perfect sized cookie.

As for the recipe-
 Definitely make sure your butter is super soft, close to melted, but not quite. When mixing it with the sugar, DON'T OVER MIX, just enough to make it all creamy & yellow. I added one extra tsp of vanilla, possibly could have used one more. They were soft, & stayed soft, even after cooling. That said, they do bake pretty quickly, so be sure to watch them close.

text:
PERFECT! I’ve tried a few other recipes on Allrecipes, this one is by far the best! Took tips from others and made sure my butter was very soft and mushy, that’s the key!  Added 2tsp vanilla, didn’t over fill my cookie scooper, rolled in sugar and cooked 9 minutes.  The centers fluffed up , we’re soft in the middle and little bit chewy on the edges . SO GOOD! This will be my go to recipe every time!

text:
These cookies were really great, with a few changes.  I followed the tips of fellow bakers, and ensured my butter was soft before using it.  Likewise, I took the cookies out right before it turned golden brown and they stayed nice and soft for the next few days.  The only additional thing I did was roll it in granulated sugar (and also mixed cinnamon / sugar to make snicker doodle cookies).  I'd make this recipe again.

text:
So, I would have given it a five star, however: The dough wasn't exactly dough, like what others have reviewed, it was hard to form, and loose and crumbly. So - I lined a cake pan (I'm sure there's no specific size needed) with Reynolds wax paper, and evenly layed out the crumbly dough in the cake pan, and baked it for about 15 minutes at 375. Then I threw some cinnamon sugar ontop, and wa-lah a pan of cookie bars/a cookie cake. Idk, but that made it hella easier than struggling to piece it. Other than that, it tasted good, maybe a little less flour would be better. I'm not really a good baker, but I love coming up with ideas for baking things when I do.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
These cookies were amazing! Just a heads up, margarine works a lot better than regular butter. As well with the margarine, make sure it is very soft or else you will get a very crumbly and hard cookie! Any way just thought I would let everyone know! Icing tastes great with these cookies, as my family ate all the ones with icing, and barely any without. In the icing I recommend using vanilla, powdered sugar, and butter until you have the taste and consistency that you prefer. Hope this can help you out, and the best of luck to those who make the cookies!

country:
None
text:
Ridiculously simple recipe. I only had 1/3 cup of butter so I adjusted the recipe and ended up with about 20 cookies, using a small cookie scoop. The taste is good, but I still prefer the traditional rolled sugar cookie style (more like a shortbread, which this is definitely not). I gave it 4 stars because it was great but didn’t “wow” me like some other cookies. I would make this again if I’m in a hurry for cookies.

text:
Very good cookies; I had to add 1/2 cup of milk because the dough was so dry and crumbly but the milk made the dough manageable (it will be sticky).  Good idea to have both butter and egg at room temp before beginning, and flatten the balls of dough before baking (8 min. total).  I used Tahitian vanilla in mine.  I would make these again; these would be good with some chopped pecans mixed in, and you might want to add a bit of salt.

Hold on to your hats ladies and gentlemen! I'm about to change your life! I used this recipe as a base for a deeper-flavored sugar cookie. I've dubbed them Caribbean Butter Cookies. To the dry ingredients,  I added cinnamon (I don't measure anything, so I can't tell you how much). To the wet ingredients,  I added fresh lemon and orange juices AND rum extract (again, not sure the exact measures). I rolled the balls of dough in sugar before baking. SHAZAM! The flavor was so so good! Thanks for such an easy and delicious base recipe!

text:
Awesome recipe! My 13 year old daughter and I decided to bake these on a rainy day. We found this recipe online and loved the simplicity.  We followed the measurements exactly as written, however, I melted the butter completely in the microwave prior to mixing with the sugar! The consistency of the finalized dough turned out perfectly and both she and I had no problems manipulating the rolled ball shapes. Cooked for 8 minutes and let set to finish the cooking process. The bottoms were a nice crisp light golden brown and the inside cooked through and soft.  I did rub canola oil on my baking sheets prior, and rolled dough balls into a bowl of sugar before baking. Perfect!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first batch turned out dry and the second two didn’t. The only difference was where I put them in the oven. Middle rack was dry and very top rack wasn’t. Also, I kind of thought the sugar to flour ratio was off from any other recipe I’ve used and the flavor confirmed that for me. If you don’t like super sweet sugar cookies (and let’s face it, they’re called sugar cookie for a reason) then you may want to skip this recipe. They taste slightly more like flour than sugar. I’ll eat them, but it’s one of those things that you eat and it only makes you think about what you could have done to make them a lot better. I think the excessive flour is what makes them so susceptible to drying out. So far it’s the least favorite sugar cookie recipe that I’ve used.

I love this recipe. Best recipe ever. It is soooooooo easy and super yummy. For me 48 servings was too much. 

I added extra vanilla extract.

This is the best dessert ever. Not to buttery unlike the other desserts.

Please follow this recipe

In fact, this is the first ever time I made any cookies. 

Awesome!!!!!!!

I am so happy.


But remember not to put to much dough on the pan and remeber to grease the parchment paper with  butter, oil or baking spray. 


Just put 5 rolls of one tablespoon of dough on the pan.


yum.

I made a few modifications. 1st I used “measure for measure” gluten-free all purpose flour (the stuff that includes the xanthan  gum). I used packed brown sugar instead of sugar. I feel like it helps make the cookies more soft and chewy.  It’s my favorite by far!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you do this recipe make sure to refrigerate the mix for 10-15 minutes before you cook it. The recipe didn’t state this in the instructions and my cookies were too soft, liquidy, and dough like after cooked for 10 minutes. If you do forget to refrigerate the mix, cook it for 2-3 minutes more. Also, this mistake will make the sugar cookies hard after 5 minutes if you cook them longer.

I think this is a good recipe. The reason I gave a four rather than a five star because it was missing salt as an ingredient. If you think these are bland that is why. I added 1/4 teaspoon. text:
Perfect.  I followed suggestions and left the butter out at room temp for several hours, and added 2 tsp vanilla.   The dough was perfect for rolling in balls- smooth and just moist enough like clay.   I baked them for 8.5 min.  They don’t brown on top, but you can see in the picture that the bottom gets a nice golden brown.  They are crispy around the edge, and soft in the center.  Just for fun and pushed in an M&M on some, and stirred in some mini chocolate chips to the rest.  Also, I baked them on parchment.  I will definitely make them again.

This recipe is great, and all of my friends say it's the best sugar cookie they've ever tasted. I did make some modifications: I baked the cookies at 350° for 11 minutes, and I flattened them to about 1 cm in height. This creates the perfect crunchy/chewy balance.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My 8 year old begged for sugar cookies but we were low on time so I appreciate how quick & way this recipe came together. My husband & kids thought they turned out great but if I try this recipe again I'll add a bit of salt & extra vanilla for more flavor. My dough was a bit sandy but my favorite chocolate chip cookie recipe is similar consistency so I wasn't afraid to go ahead and bake them. I have a feeling the consistency would have been better with margarine. Cook time of 8 mins made a softer cookie  but 10 mins gave a prettier, more firm result. Since the dough was a tad dry it was harder to roll in sprinkles bit I dabbed a little water on them to hold toppings and that worked fine. I'm underwhelmed but I'm a chocolate chip gal so maybe that's why. Simple enough for the next time kids want sugar cookies :)

text:
So I followed the recipe and my dough came out crumbly. I added sprinkles of cold water slowly and kneaded until the dough stuck together and I could work with it. Then I rolled it out and was able to use cookie cutters. The taste was good, but I like putting frosting, sprinkles, etc to liven them up. They are crunchy, but if you frost them the night before, when the frosting dries the next day they come out nice and moist.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you bake these cookies for too long they get too hard! Adjust the amount of time depending on the size of your cookies. I kept mine in for max time, but I made big cookies. My second batch turned out so perfect. The cookie dough is very crumbly but presses together nicely. I thought I had ruined the cookies my first time. I have soft chewy sugar cookies that do not need icing or milk to dip them in. My family loves these. Oh but I did use almond extract instead of vanilla, it kicks these sugar cookies up a notch! Now I’m off to try a new chocolate chip recipe and make family eat tons of cookies.

That said, I left my butter out (as another reviewer suggested) for over 24 hours and it was beyond soft and the dough was still crumbly.  The cookies tasted good but are drier in the middle and definitely not soft and chewy.  I think I'll stick to being patient and making sugar cookies that refrigerate so I get the end result I want.

city:

country:
None
text:
Response to those who rated these poorly....
Making good cookies can be like making good bread- meaning it takes practice and patience.  A couple things that would have helped in the instructions for these gems.... when mixing the butter and sugar, it’s necessary to let the beater run for a good 6-7 min.  Using a stand mixer helps.  You are actually creaming- a technique that is way more than mixing.  It breaks down the fats in the butter and results in a super tender cookie.  Second, a light hand with flour is best for cookies.  DON’T pack down flour tightly and then level off with a knife.  Stir the flour you are using first to loosen it, then lightly fill a cup and shake off the excess.  These two things will prevent hard, crumbly cookies that don’t form into a ball- which is what the bad reviews mention.  These sugar cookies are excellent and definitely a keeper.  If you messed up a batch they are worth a redo!  Sugar cookies this simple and quick are hard to come by.  Also, I didn’t try it, but after forming the balls I’m pretty sure this dough would make a good cut out cookie.

Even with the butter completely softened (as was suggested in another review) the dough was still too dry. I added about a tablespoon of whole milk in to it  and it worked. I would suggest also cooking it for only 8 or so min instead of waiting for it to brown a bit for a softer cookie. 
I plan on making this again with the adjustments that I mentioned.

text:
Plan to make these today subbing marg for butter, and making sure the margarine IS COMPLETELY SOFTENED like mush, and using two teaspoons of vanilla instead of one to give it a little more flavor.  Extra 1/4 tsp salt. Mixing longer if batter is too crumbly. Only doing a teaspoon of batter for each cookie...they really expand while baking. Baking for 8 minutes and then let them sit on the cookie sheet for about 5 minutes and then move them to the cookie rack.

text:
This recipe is my number one all time fail and I will never ever make it again. I read the reviews, and tried my first double batch with margarine. They completely melted and ran off the cookie sheet in the oven. The second night I did it with butter. This time, they remained doughy little balls that tasted of raw flour after baking for nearly 13 minutes (the recipe says 8-10). I am the fool for three reasons. 1) I have used this site before and have had little to no success with their published recipes, the only reason I used again is because it was second on the list for sugar cookies, 2) after the first fail, I tried it again, and 3) I should have trusted the bad reviews, listened to my gut and found another recipe.  In nearly 40 years of baking cookies never have I run into such a bad recipe.

text:
Amazing recipe!!  I used Margarine becuase A) I dont use butter and B) its always soft for cookies.  This batter was like silk!! was so smooth and delicious.  the best part was you did not have to be really picky about the cookie balls - they fell around the same shape every time!  I cooked them at 300 degrees for 8-9 minutes - anything longer and they went a bit brownish.  a little too golden crispy for my liking.  These cookies really aren't too sweet so if you like a really "Sugary" sugar cookie - you could add more sugar to this or maybe some liquid sweetener?  Very easy cookie and makes quite a bit.  Saved this one for the future.

text:
Very good base recipe; I added salt as well as allspice and black pepper,  and subbed the white sugar for brown. I don't think I would make this recipe without salt, even if I didn't add extra spices or change the sugar. Bakes to a really nice texture, especially when the butter is partially or wholly melted.

text:
My son made these and made sure the butter was mush. They were still dry and crumbly. An extra egg was needed to make the cookie dough come together. He also added an extra teaspoon of extract. It was excellent after the added egg and vanilla extract. My son rolled out the dough and cut out into Xmas shapes. He then chilled them over night and popped them in the oven and they retained their shape really well!! Made about two dozen, soft, thick sugar cookies!

text:
I followed some of the reviews and added 2tsp of vanilla instead of one. I also made sure my butter was extra soft before making, which helped it to mix properly. Overall, it's a good sugar cookie recipe, though not the best I've ever had. This made a little over 4 dozen cookies. We followed the tsp rule when portioning them out. They spread out to about palm sided after baking.  Also, a tip: when rolling them in your hands, spray your hands with cooking spray to keep from sticking.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made 3 batches of thees. One without mixer and 2 with a  mixer. You need to use the mixer!!!! Also, if you don't use mixer, your cookie will be rock hard and the dough will crumble. The butter needs to be melted. I added milk to the dough to make it better. My mom told me to chill it for and hour and i did it for a day. Then i baked it. The cookie tastes great, but the texture is awful. Don't make thees if you have braces like me or other mouth things or issues. You need to add a lot more that one tablespoon of vanilla  and i added water too.  And if the dough can not be rolled out, you can not use it. If you do more that 10 minuets, they become like a rock. Only bake them for 8 and  take them out immediately I will not be making these again.

text:
They're not the chewiest, most flavorful sugar cookies on Earth (they taste just fine!), but they get five stars from me because they're just so. darn. easy. to. make.  If you need a last-minute cookie that you can throw together in 20 minutes with stuff you have in your pantry, this is it. I come back to this recipe again and again, whenever I forget I've been invited to a potluck until the night before. Convenient, and one step up from buying supermarket cookies (hey, you think, at least it looks like I tried--they're "home-made!")

Display Name:
Amy Bausher

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am not a very good cookie baker at all! My cookies are usually soft until they cool and then become rocks. But these came out perfect! My butter wasn't room temperature so I put in the microwave for 20 seconds on 40% power. It came out perfectly soft. I cut the sugar in half, added an extra teaspoon of vanilla, and a pinch of salt. I rolled them into 1 1/2 inch balls and squished them down a bit so I could add sprinkles. I cooked them on the rack just above center on non-stick cookie sheets until they were very slightly browned on the bottom and the center looked just done. They are the perfect texture, consistency, flavor and sweetness. The best sugar cookie I have ever made!

Very good cookies!  I followed the recipe almost exactly.  I did add 1/4 teaspoon salt even though I was using salted butter and I rolled them in red sugar before I baked them. text:
These were really easy to make and tasted great! I read on a blog that sugar cookies should have equal parts butter and sugar so I added 1 1/8 cup of sugar (extra 1/8 because I was a little worried the cookies would be too bland) and 1.5 tsp of vanilla extract.  Next time I will just add 1 cup of sugar.  These were by far the easiest sugar cookies I’ve ever made.  I dipped1 tsp of dough in sprinkles and baked them for 8 min.  Will be using this recipe for all holiday and bake sale cookies!

text:
This was an easy recipe to follow! I recommend taking the butter out a couple hours before prep and letting it get mushy. Also DO NOT OVER COOK! 10 minutes is perfect, I tried baking them for 12 and they got hard. If you like your cookies hard go for 11 but take them out and only let them cool for 1 minute before moving them to a cooling rack!  Overall really easy and perfect treat!

I'm making some this weekend for a 50th anniversary party and plan on rolling them in some gold-colored sugar I found at Wal-Mart, hopefully they look sparkly! city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are great cookies! They're perfect and absolutely the best I've ever eaten or tried to make. They make a great base for other types of cookies. For example, if I want chocolate chip cookies, I add cocoa powder and chocolate chips, if I want cookies and cream, I just add some crushed Oreos. When I've tried to make it in smaller batches, it didn't expand, and the sugar flavor didn't carry through as much. But this is because I added too much flour, and needed to add milk. So, DO NOT add milk, if your batter is too dry, you probably messed something up. But, if you add too MUCH flour, it will completely flatten out, and will taste hard, like brittle.

country:
None
text:
Ok, so I made a few changes to this recipe, but this was a great base recipe! I made the recipe without baking powder, and substituted 1/2 cup of the white sugar with brown. The brown sugar makes them very crisp and richly flavored enough to eat without needing any icing, almost like shortbread. I cooked half on a cookie sheet and they turned out soft with lovely crisp bottoms! Best of both worlds! The other half I cooked in mini muffin pans which created lovely cake-like bites. I added a little strawberry jam to the middles after baking. Delightful! Definitely follow the advice of the other reviewers to make the butter super soft (but not melted). Will do this one again!

text:
Great recipe!  This is the first time I have made them.  Per the other reviews, I added additional vanilla. I wanted larger cookies so I doubled the recipe.  
To make them come out  bigger, I made the dough balls out of heaping tablespoons, rolled in sugar and slightly flattened with the bottom of a heavy glass.  Made about 48, 3 1/2" - 4" cookies out of the double batter.  Baked for a little over 9 minutes.

text:
these came out amazing exactly like the picture too I added chocolate chips to one batch and then sprinkles to another batch. If you are interested in making the chocolate chip sugar cookies all you need to do is add 1 cup of chocolate chips to your regular sugar cookie dough and then put them in your pre heated oven at 375 degrees they must stay in the oven for EXACTLY 9 MINUTES. Have fun baking and enjoy this recipe!!!! :)

text:
It was really good!  I mushed up the butter, to help it soften faster (because you really need it softened) but it was crunchy on the outside and super soft on the inside. My trick was: When you have the batter all mixed up and ready to be made into balls, put a SMALL ball into the microwave for at least 30 sec. and it will show you how it will taste in the end.  I admit, it was kind of a plain cookie, but I bet we could've fixed that by adding sprinkles into the batter or putting frosting on top.  My family loved it.

Display Name:
bettytwo

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Salt people! These cookies need salt! A saltless cookie is a tasteless cookie. Many of the reviewers said these cookies had no flavor, and I don't need to make them to know the lack of salt is the reason. I AM going to make them, but will be adding
3/4 tsp. of salt and using salted butter as well.  If one were to use unsalted butter and no added salt, the result would be bland and completely without flavor. Salt is your friend when making cookies (and cakes, and doughnuts, and pie crust, and almost any other type of baked goods). I have found that 1/2 tsp. salt to 1 1/2 cups of flour is the right ratio. The next time you see a cookie recipe with no salt, run away. Either that or add some salt.
Review:
Rating:
1

2018-07-14T21:29:21.533

Robyn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7573597.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The cookies are very soft, almost spongy.  Very plain, though, and not with much flavor even though I doubled the vanilla as others did.  They'd be great frosted.  I baked half of it on a cookie sheet for the crust of fruit pizza and that worked great.
The dough was very soft for me, about the consistency of brownie mix, I heard others say they had too stiff of dough.  I
even added some extra flour, worrying I'd have very flat cookies, but I think they would have been fine.  (maybe that was why they were a little spongy).  Nonetheless, my kids liked them quite well.  I'm not sure if I'll be making them again, however because I already have a  great sugar cookie recipe and the dough is a better consistency to roll out and shape the cookies--and that's even without refrigeration.  I question how well these would work, even with refrigeration for a couple hours due to the consistency of dough that I had.

So easy to make and light and delicious. Made it for before an event that I had forgotten about, and this helped so much! I did change the vanilla extract to almond extract and that worked really well, and I made them tablespoon-sized instead of teaspoon-sized, and upped the baking time to 15 minutes. I'd suggest this recipe for making a quick, yummy treat.

text:
Very easy sugar cookie when you don’t wanna roll!  I started with 2 1/2 C of flour, and see how it is coming together. I probably end up using between 2 1/2 to just under 2 3/4 C each time. I mix until it’s a good solid dough but not crumbly (previous mistake).  I often throw multi coloured sprinkles in for a kick of color.  A favorite for lunch boxes or coffee!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very yummy and easy to make! After a recommendation from another review, I added another tsp of vanilla for more flavor and glad I did! And I only baked for 8 min instead of the full 10 and the cookies came out perfectly chewy. The recipe didn’t specify whether or not to use salted or unsalted butter and I used unsalted butter like I normally do with baking, so next time I may add 1/8 tsp of salt to the recipe to bring out a little more of the sweetness. Also, a little tip, make sure the dough is mixed really well! When I got to the bottom of my bowl I noticed I didn’t mix it that great down there so the dough became a little crumbly, so I had to throw some of the dough balls back in and remix the rest. But other than that, easy and delicious recipe!

text:
These were delicious, and super easy!  Be sure to cream the butter and sugar, and then beat it until fluffy after adding eggs and vanilla.  I find this makes a difference in the texture, and in how the dough handles.  If you want softer texture, use 1 cup white sugar and 1/2 cup brown. I also like to add 1/4 tsp salt and a 2nd tsp of vanilla.  Scooped using a leveled ice cream scooper and did not flatten, and the shape was perfect and didn't spread.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
overall pretty okay possible to improve though
so i dunno but i kinda thought it tasted like custard flavoured cookies which tasted okay but weren't what i was looking for. so here's what i did the second time i baked them
- these spread alOT. when you're balling them keep them teaspoon sized
- use slightly less than a whole egg. my first try came out really eggy
- remove them when they start turning slightly brown at the edges, they turn much too crispy after that + they continue baking even after you remove the tray
- i added a bit more vanilla essence than in the recipe to give  abit more flavour

cheers!

text:
The only thing about this recipe is the cookies tasted decent.  I made two different batches. One I used oil, the dough was crumby and pretty much like sand. They were impossible to roll into a ball because the dough was so dry. After baking, they were still balls and never flattened out. I figured I did something wrong so I made another batch, but used melted butter instead.  The dough still came out dry as sand and they barely flattened out. I made sure I mixed the wet ingredients until smooth and creamy. I should have added an extra egg or some milk, or reduced the amount of flour.  Won't be using this recipe again.
