text:
This is a fabulous sugar cookie recipe! I was in one of those nostalgic moods last night and I wanted to make some cookies like my grandma and I used to make. I don't have her recipe for sugar cookies, and these were just perfect! The only substitution I made was using butter flavor Crisco in place of the butter. I find my cookies come out better and stay soft and chewy longer when I use this instead of butter. The can calls to add 2 T. of water for every cup of Crisco when replacing it with butter, which I did. Dipped the top of each one in multicolored nonpareils sprinkles, just like grandma and I used to do! Thank you for sharing this fantastic (and simple) recipe!

text:
Cut the recipe in half because I didn't want to use a whole stick of butter for the event we were attending. Still used one egg and I used 1.5 tsp of vanilla based on others' reviews. These came out perfect. Make sure your butter is completely softened and take them out just as you start to see them turning brown on the bottom. Let them cool and they should be perfect. They were soft and chewy, reminded me of Pillsbury/Kroger brand mix.

text:
One night my husband and I had a craving for cookies but didn't have a lot of ingredients in the house. So I looked up a simple cookie recipe that we could make and I found this. Reading the reviews I was like,  "People calm down it's only cookies!" But once I made them I understood how fantastic this recipe is. The cookies are a wonderful soft but slightly chewy texture and the flavor is great. I used real butter and it's true you have to make sure the butter is extremely soft almost melted before you mix in the sugar. The only thing I did different was to roll them in cinnamon sugar before baking. I took them to work and everyone raved. Then I took them to a family dinner and everyone raved. I would highly recommend making these cookies. They really are as good as everyone says.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
**ADVICE**
I made these cookies and I followed the recipe perfectly, and I knew that something wasn't right when my dough (Like many other's) turned out crumbly and hard to shape. I had used pretty much liquid butter so I knew that wasn't the problem, so I tried anyways even though I knew it was wrong. The cookies came out hard and kinda gross, so I re-did them and this time I highly suggest that if your dough comes out crumbly, melt a few chunks of butter in the microwave and mix more in until it comes out the way it should. It helped me a lot, and they turned out way better. Hope you benefited from this :D

I'm in foods class and when we made sugar cookies, everyone's batter was crumbly. BUT, if you keep mixing for a long time, it will turn out just fine. it's supposed to be crumbly at first and then it goes to batter. JUST KEEP MIXING, mine turned out great! (also i would use a electric mixer, not a whisk)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I came across this recipe a couple years ago now and continuously use it to this day. All my friends and family cannot get enough, and have had friends begging for the recipe to be passed on. It's an easy recipe that yields a lot! It is critical that the butter is softened so keep that in mind before baking, but whenever I find the dough on the crumbly/dryer side a little splash of milk fixes that right up. The dough is easily manipulated into shapes, and because they are sugar cookies very versatile for toppings. Personally I prefer the cookies soft and chewy so I never exceed 8min baking time. For Valentine's Day I got together a box of goodies for my boyfriend which included these cookies, and I still here about how good they were from him. Very good, easy cookies. Will be a stable in my home for a long time coming! Thanks for sharing!!

userID:
21823797
Display Name:
kathy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made them I didn't care for them (my husband did) but I thought they looked like a scone although the taste was there they were hard. I decided to try again and what a difference, The butter I creamed by hand first then I mixed the egg and vanilla in. I mixed it longer than first time and it got super creamy. I added the flour Slowly and continued mixing. It started to look like a dough and was clogging my beater it looked like heavy peanut butter consistency. I then used a teaspoon to get the dough and rolled it to balls. The first time I didn't I made them entirely too big. I got 42 cookies this time compared to 24 last. I tried a few different things, I dipped in sugar in ball form. Iused a glass to flatten and put sprinkle on and I top a few with chocolate morsels. The best looking cookies were the ones I flattened. They spread beautiful and cooked best, I added cinnamon sugar to a few like snickerdoodles that are great. I think your oven temp is another reason for failing. I left mine in 9 minutes and they are good. I would like them a little harder and would prob try another minute or two but they do melt and your mouth now. It is hard to believe this was the same recipe that made my first batch. Keep trying and play with this recipe . It super easy and once you get it right you will love them Just take a little longer mixing and youll do great!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Judging by many of the photos I'd seen on people who made these cookies, I almost didn't make them. So many people posted photos of burned cookies, poorly decorated ones,  or cookies that resulted in odd shapes. Needless to say the presentation wasn't appealing to my appetite. I decided to give this recipe a chance anyway. I made these EXACTLY how the recipe stated. I made sure that I rolled them into perfect 1 tbsp sized balls and used a non-stick cookie sheet. I left them in there for about 8 minutes and they turned out perfect with no odd shapes resulting and no burned bottoms. I also made them a second time and turned them into snickerdoodles by rolling the balls into a cinnamon sugar mixture right before I placed them into the oven. They were delicious!  Best sugar cookie recipe I ever had! Thanks for sharing!

text:
My grandma brought ingredients for sugar cookies for Christmas Eve.  The problem was: We didn't have any recipes!!!  I looked up sugar cookie recipes, and of course, this website was my first stop.  We found this recipe and said, "Hey, let's give it a try!".  The preparation was absolutely no problem, AT ALL. After we took them out of the oven, iced them with cream cheese icing, and put on some sprinkles, they were to die for!!!  I love this recipe and bookmarked it.  Whoever made this recipe, well done.

These cookies truly couldn’t be an easier! While the name of them is fitting they deserve something that sounds much more delightful! I followed the recipe with one addition, lemon zest.  I rolled each Tbsp in sugar (refined, colored and crystal), baked for 8 minutes then cooled.  The edges had a slight crunch and the center was soft and wonderful! I wish I would’ve pulled more butter from the fridge because I don’t know if these will last a Day! What will Santa get if we eat them all?

text:
These are the best sugar cookies I have ever made. The only thing I did different was using 2 tsp Vanilla instead of one. The only way to mess up this recipe is to over cook the cookies. I took mine out of the oven at exactly 8 minutes and then left them on the tray for 2-3 minutes. Everyone loved them. And I did NOT use soft butter. I took it from the fridge and beat it with the sugar while it was still cold. I'm getting ready to make a triple batch right now. Fantastic recipe.

text:
These cookies are wonderful, however I did make a couple adjustments, hence the 4 instead of 5 stars. I completed the batter as suggested, however it was dry and crumbly so I did not add the last 1/4 cup of the flour mixture, I added a second egg and a second teaspoon of vanilla. Took out of the oven at exactly 8 minutes based on other reviews and only put 8 cookies per sheet and I’m glad i did as they spread quite a bit. Delicious! A big hit in our house today!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This sugar cookie recipe is amazing!!! I altered 2 things slightly. Instead of 1 tsp of vanilla, I did 1/2 tsp vanilla and a 1/2 tsp almond extract. I also used 1 stick unsalted and 1 stick salted butter. I baked at 350 for exactly 8 mins, and they came out perfect! I rolled the dough out and did cut out cookies instead of  the drop cookies. Initially the dough was crumbly. I just dumped it out on a flat surface with a dusting of powdered sugar and I kneeded it until it came together. They were chewy and just slightly crunchy on the outside. Will definitely be making these again!!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4620091.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read through reviews before making these, and I did not have the issues many people had.  I needed to make 8 dozen "fun" cookies for a church event, so I figured several batches of different tinted sugar cookies would be the easiest.  I made both a gluten and gluten-free version and both turned out _exactly the same_.  I tasted both.  If you've ever had to eat gluten free, you know how incredibly amazing that is.  

I read that margarine works best, so I bought a tub of Imperial, which is insanely salty and added the missing salt.  For the gluten version I let the entire tub go completely soft then measured it out.  The sugar and margarine never went "smooth."  The margarine actually separated out and left a very grainy look.  I went ahead and beat in the egg and a tablespoon of vanilla hoping it would work out.  Then I added the flour/baking power/baking soda, which I sifted TWICE before adding.  Sifting it lets the baking powder and soda blend into the flour, so it's not unevenly spread among the dough.  The dough turned out incredibly sticky and running.  There was no possible way to "roll" it so I chilled the gluten dough in the fridge for an hour then baked the first batch using a cookie scoop.  They turned out incredibly fluffy and delicious.  

For the gluten free version, I used Pillsbury cup for cup "best" gluten free flour.  I used 2 1/2 cups of flour and 2/3 cups of margarine, simply because I ran out of flour.   I used two teaspoons of vanilla.  I also did not l
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2017-12-06T02:54:21.373
helpfulCount:

text:
As an Au Pair, I am always looking for fun recipes to prepare with the children, and I can highly recommend this one. The mother of the home was very impressed as well. I added another teaspoon of vanilla and a tiny pinch of cinnamon for extra flavor. If you like gooey cookies, aim for 7-8 minutes in the oven. If you like crunchy cookies, aim for 9-10 minutes instead. These truly are the perfect sugar cookies: simple and sweet.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very easy cookie.  Did not use butter . Substituted  Land-O-Lakes butter with canola oil.  Added an extra 1tsp vanilla,  1/2 cup flaked coconut,  1/2 cup chopped pecans and 1/2 cup  dried cranberries. Mashed dough balls with bottom of a glass.  Very tasty with a good butter flavor.  You can also add dark chocolate chips, press a few onto dough balls and mash down with fork.

Display Name:
Tara Williams
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If someone was trying to make edible sand and messed up, they would get this recipe in its raw state. 
I wrongly assumed that the first recipe that popped up on Google would lead me to a good cookie. I was very wrong.
First of all, both baking powder and soda aren't necessary. Pick one you like, use about a teaspoon and move on. If you add too much (and this recipe really straddles the line here), you will have a bitter, inedible mess.
Add salt. Like, even a quarter teaspoon will do. Everybody worth their salt adds salt to pastry recipes. Duh. Let's consult Irma Rombauer herself here: "The power of salt to heighten the flavor of other foods is its greatest culinary asset. ...[A] pinch of salt often brings out a confection's characteristic best."
Either cut down the flour or add another egg. This is the major culprit for the sandy quality of the unedited dough. If you're going to cut flour, I'd suggest leaving out at least half a cup of the suggested amount. Putting sand in the oven only dries it out--cookie dough benefits more from being baked.
I gave this recipe 2 stars because it wasn't like it put chicken in the ingredients list or anything.
Review:
Rating:
5

2017-09-04T05:11:37.427

None
text:
This was a GREAT recipe with some changes. I made it vegan (used Earth Balance butter and replaced the egg with 1/4 cup applesauce and 1/2 tsp baking powder) and it still came out great, but I also quadrupled the vanilla (4 tsp, not 1!) which really made them perfect. Another reviewer said not to leave them in for 10 minutes, and I agree. I found a little under 9 minutes to be perfect. I didn't let the tops brown, only crack a bit, but the undersides were a perfect golden brown, and they stayed very moist after cooling. Such a good cookie with some adjustments!

text:
OK I read lots of reviews before I made these cookies firstly they are fantastic, so I melted my butter completely in the micro mixed the butter and sugar in my mixer  have  (arthritis) with the result they were too soft to roll, so I put the mixture in the fridge it soon hardened up for me to roll  in balls I used my cookie scoop and it made 38 I would say normal size cookies. The only change I made to the ingredients was I put extra vanilla extract and a little cinnamon and rolled the cookies in sugar mixed with a little cinnamon before putting them in the oven. You must watch them as they can burn very easily I lost 6 as I thought they needed 2 more minutes and they were too brown and tasted a little burnt also, this recipe is definitely  a keeper next  time I will put less sugar as they were a tad too sweet for me, I might also try  some cocoa to make choc cookies

We added food coloring for a splash of color.  The cookies aren't quite as sugary as our family likes, but with some icing or sugar topping, they'd be a bit better. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Some suggestions for first time bakers:

-Make the butter mushy, but not too mushy. Leave it in room temperature until the butter is still slightly cold to touch, but just mushy enough so you can indent it with a little pressure from your finger. 

-If the dough is too dry, add another egg or add some milk 
-Add a little bit more vanilla extract than instructed. They'll turn out MUCH more flavorful. 
-Follow the recipe closely, make sure to add dry ingredients gradually

-Remember: Baking Soda makes the cookies spread, while Baking Powder makes the cookies rise. 

-Take them out at 8 minutes for a soft and chewy texture, 9 minutes for slightly crunchy, and any time longer the cookies will turn out hard once you take them out. 

-The dough will look dry at first but keep mixing for 3+ minutes and it should be fine. 

-Use a hand mixer for the dough. 

I LOVED this recipe. The only reason I give it a 4.5 - ish is because the cookies came out with a bit of a floury aftertaste and there was too much sugar (ironically) for my taste. 

Otherwise a wonderful recipe. Simple yet delicious. I would definitely recommend this for a quick and easy dessert to enjoy with friends and family.

My husband and I made this and the batter came out dry and I knew we did something wrong.  I then came a read the comments and saw Rolanda's comment that the butter needs to be really soft. I knew though that it was not to late to fix the  batter and so we added oil. For a double batch we added a 5th of a cup of oil to soften it up. I hope this helped anyone who had the same problem as we did.

text:
I"m giving it 3 stars because. 1. I made these at work for the residents, and the cookie batter turned out perfect, the cookies turned out perfect too, and the residents gave their compliments. However; when I made these at home for my hubby, the batter was crumbly and dry. So, to remedy this...I added 1/2 cup plain Greek Yogurt. Which added moisture, and the cookies were great after that.
 2)  I truly believe the difference between the 2 tries, were the ingredients. Either the flour or butter, or both were different.  My hubby will still eat them, they have great flavor and are more like cake/biscuits. But my first try at work, the cookies looked more like the photo on here. I'm going to make some more and figure out what the secret is.

text:
Hey! So I used this one as a "foundation" recipe! I used the following instead!

1 3/4 cups of white sugar and 1/4 cup of brown sugar
2 eggs (which added to the chewiness!)
1 tablespoon of Vanilla extract 
I also used self rising flour (it was all that  I had!)
I also rolled the cookies in sugar before baking! They came out very chewy and full of flavor and sweetness

Also, I don't have a blender and had to whisk and stir the mixture by hand. 

Hope this helps!

userID:
21809516
Display Name:
Tara Michelle Dactyl
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my lord.

I'm a chocolate chip cookie kind of gal, not sugar cookie (my figure shows this well). When I made these cookies last minute for a party, I had to test one, because I hate taking food that doesn't taste good. They're amazing! Simple, easy, and some of the best tasting sugar cookies I've ever had. The one thing I was skeptical on was the fact I couldn't find out how many this made. I got a yield of around 45-50 cookies (including the ones I ate), they're all good sized. The greatest thing about this recipe is that even though you'll have multiple batches (like I did), the cookies take 2 minutes to cool on the cookie sheet, and about 5-6 to cool on the rack, so everything will be steadily moving while your other cookies are baking, but not too quickly to where you can't keep up.

This recipe is amazing, and definitely follow the directions. If you don't let the butter soften for about 10-15 minutes at room temp then they will come out crumbly and gross. Let the butter soften and you'll have an amazing, soft cookie!

5

Very good as is (the rating is for the recipe as written), but not quite what I had hoped for, so I tried the following and yielded better results (5 star):  For a better texture, I used half unsalted butter and half shortening, and increased the flour to 3 cups.  I also increased the vanilla to TWO teaspoons.  Lastly, I added a pinch of salt.  Before baking, I rolled the cookies in colored sugar for more flavor and decor.

Display Name:
Susan T

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm experimenting w/ Sugar Cookie recipes to find the best one because they're delicious.  I baked these twice this week to test out various bake times and ingredients.
1) Add a total of 1.5 teaspoons of vanilla
2) I added 1/2 vanilla bean too b/c it adds good flavor
3) Add a tablepoon of milk, if the dough is too dry and crumbly. Add another until it's roll-able.
4) Roll the top half of the dough ball  in sparkling sugar (those big crystals that don't melt).  It looks nicer and adds crunch w/o all the extra sweetness of regular sugar
5) I baked at 375 for 8:30 min
 Note:  don't flatten w/ the bottom of glass, they come out looking weird (see my picture)

country:
None
text:
These are great cookies if you make them right. The tip of softening the butter is a age old tale. You do not have to have it mush to start. When the directions say cream with sugar it means to put it in your mixer and let it go for about five minutes until it has a nice smooth look. This softens the butter and breaks the sugar down into the mix better. Happy Eating.

city:

country:

text:
UPDATE: after baking these again, I made a couple adjustments. Doubling the vanilla, I decided, made the alcohol detectable, so this time I just used 1.5 tsp. It was the perfect amount for a very vanilla-y flavor! I also cut bake time by a minute (down to 8 min), and it made for the perfect consistency. Very soft: gooey on inside, crisp on outside. Just make sure they cool a bit before removing off the pan, or else they'll fall apart. Lastly, I reserved 1/4 c. sugar from the dough recipe and used that 1/4 c. to roll the dough balls in. Before I had just added the sugar to roll in and they were a bit too sweet. Cutting that amount from the recipe made them just perfect! Alternatively, you could sprinkle a little sugar on the tops only and keep the recipe the same. I assume this would yield a similar result.

ORIGINAL POST: I'm still in the middle of baking these, but I had to run to my computer to write a review! THESE ARE AMAZING! Bookmark this page and put Google away, because you need not look ANY further! I think every baker needs 2 good sugar cookie recipes: one for cutting out shapes, and one for your standard "drop" cookies. This recipe is just perfect for the latter! Just make sure you use real butter and not margarine. I'm also obsessed with vanilla, so I doubled it to 2 tsp. I also rolled the balls of dough in sugar prior to baking to make a standard, sparkly sugar cookie. 9 minutes of bake time was perfect in my oven. And they're so PRETTY! Perfectly cracked tops th

So I made this recipe and I made it exactly as it says, but it came out dry and crumbly, almost like a shortbread style cookie dough. I ended up adding another egg and it came out fine, except when you ball them up, make sure to squish them down by hand a little bit because they don't spread very much otherwise. And if you use slated butter, then there is no necessity for salt to be added. I also made a second batch and added 1/2 cup peanut butter and they came out beautifully and delicious!

text:
These are awesome sugar cookies; the best recipe I've found yet! However, the recipe says that this batch can make 48 cookies... I've never gotten more than 24 out of this recipe! (rolling regular sized cookie balls) Just something for you guys to consider! :) I also use a 1/4 cup less of flour than it calls for. I feel that using that 2 3/4 cups of flours make the cookie dough too crumbly. I'm making these for a Christmas party and I added red food coloring to the dough and then added green sprinkles on top once the dough was rolled into balls. BUT, I highly recommend this recipe! It's super easy and super quick, plus they're delicious!!!

text:
WOW! I cannot describe how amazingly fantastic and wonderful these cookies are! Whoever invented this recipe should win a nobel prize! I would've given these ten stars if could. These were the best cookies I've ever baked! The best anything I've ever made, really! I did use two teaspoons of coffee creamer to replace the vanilla because we ran out, and I also added walnuts, but they were a hit! My whole family LOVED them! My grandma had seconds, and she never eats cookies because she's dieting! My mom had fourths, and she doesn't even like sugar cookies!  And they were SO EASY! I LOVE that you don't have to roll them out and refrigerate them like most sugar cookies. I always make peanut butter cookies because they're easy, but these are just as easy and WAY more worth it. Plus, baking makes me thirsty and gets me moving, so these are kind of benefitting my health in a way. Plus, I'm in seventh grade, so if I can do it, anyone can! I'll be making these weekly!

text:
I will admit, I had some trouble with this recipe. The first batch I made got very hard and crumbly upon cooling, which was fine with my fiance because that's how he likes cookies, but I like softer cookies. I read through some other reviews and many people have suggested leaving the butter out for longer so it's wicked soft. I only let it warm up enough to cream it, so I'm guessing that's where my problem began. Other people mentioned taking the cookies out of the oven "too soon," as in after eight minutes when they aren't golden-brown yet. I will be trying this next time.

Aside from this, the cookies themselves were delicious and I'm glad I tried this recipe!

text:
Super good! I followed the recipe  a tee and they came out great. I put my butter sticks in the microwave for 20 seconds to get them soft. I also pressed the rolled ball dough with a cup to make a nice round disk before I stuck them in the oven. 10 minutes in the oven made for a harder cookie which was great for icing, 8 minutes was great for a softer cookie.

userID:
21066317
Display Name:
Shauna W.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are great, super easy sugar cookies. As  some have mentioned, some slight tweaks are necessary to get them perfect.  I ended up making these 2 nights in a row. The first night I followed the recipe as is and while they were still good, they weren't great. They were not as moist or as flavorful as I would have liked. So, the second night I made them, I used only 2 1/2 cups of flour instead of the 2 3/4 that the recipe calls for. That made a world of difference! The texture and flavor came out perfect. It allowed the butter and vanilla flavors to come through more. Even my husband who does not like sugar cookies actually really enjoyed them.  Also, the baking time makes a big difference. 8 minutes is good for soft cookies and 10 is good for nice crisp cookies.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-12-22T23:36:40.497
helpfulCount:
0

text:
It seemed more reasonable to trust the majority of the reviewers who genuinely loved this recipe as opposed to those few who didn't!  Well, I have found my new sugar cookie recipe.  I was skeptical about the amount of flour and the lack of salt but I decided to try it as-is and take it from there. I lowered the sugar by 1/4 cup because my husband's not a fan of "too sweet" and I added 1T of vanilla because I love the flavor, especially in my sugar cookies.  I couldn't be happier with how these turned out! They are super easy and quick to make and the dough doesn't require chilling.  Win win!! If you're wondering about these cookies, I'd encourage you to make a batch today.  I'm glad I did!

text:
I made a few changes and these cookies were pretty amazing...family ate the entire batch before they cooled!
I used half butter and half coconut oil, creamed together first, then I substituted all white sugar for 1 cup white sugar and 1/2 cup brown sugar. I also doubled the amount of vanilla, added 2 eggs not 1, put in some cinnamon, ginger, and cardamom. I also added a 1/4 cup finely shredded coconut.  Cooked at 350 for 12 minutes.

text:
Wonderful!!!  I had been seriously craving sugar cookies and these delivered!  I doubled the vanilla and after trial and error, (and by error I mean not quite perfect ones for me to taste), had the best results leaving them in ball shape instead of flattening slightly like I convinced myself I needed to...but don't worry, they'll bake up perfectly!  Mine were done at 9 minutes and my oven tends to run a little hot.  (My cookie balls were just shy of walnut-sized).  Like the recipe says-don't let them brown!!  Options are endless for additions.  I used Christmas sprinkles (jimmies) in the batter and dunked the tops in the sprinkles before baking and they're gorgeous.  Next time I'll add cinnamon to the batter and dunk the balls in spiced sugar before baking.  These are a classic!

These cookies came out really nice, but only after I followed direction of the most helpful critical review.

The first time I made these, the dough came out really dry and crumbly. I was confused, thinking I forgot a liquid ingredient. After trying again, but MELTING my butter this time, they came out perfectly. I think the recipe needs to explicitly say that the butter needs to be extremely soft or melted. 

Other than that, they came out really nice and tasty. It's nice that they only need a few simple ingredients.

text:
I made these cookies to gift to my neighbors this Holiday Season. I made as stated, except by adding 1/4 tsp of salt ( little salt is important in the overall  taste of sweets). I dipped 1 side of the cookie dough balls in colored sugar and baked for 8 minutes. The cookies came out delicious. They were soft and chewy. The problem was in the look. They were flat ! And I made sure not to flatten, at all, the dough balls ! Also the dough was crumbly. And, it wasn't because of cold butter, I had the butter out of the fridge hours ahead. I think the ratio of dry ingredients to wet ones is off.

text:
Amazing cookies, I used the TIP at the bottom to make easier clean-up, and 2 tsp. of Vanilla Extract instead to give it more of a vanilla taste. And I used a large ice cream scooper and floured my hands to help make the dough balls. Something I didn't know, which I'm glad I looked, no need to smash the cookies down they will flatten in the oven. **I also left my cookies in for only 8 minutes; they came out so soft.** To keep them longer (well as long as they would last) I placed them in a storage bag. I WILL be making these again.

text:
3 weeks ago I found out at the last minute we needed cookies for a bake sale for my cousin.  I found this recipe.  I love it did not need to be refrigerated first...

We made a triple batch of the recipe and found it was to dry...so we added: 1 egg, 2 tsp more of vanilla and 1 more stick of butter. That bought the dough to the right consistency for the cookies.

Today I was asked for the recipe, so I printed out, and made it according to the recipe,  it came out perfectly no adjustment needed. 

Then I made a second gluten free batch. I used an all purpose gluten-free flour  in place of the flour,  equal cup for cup measure-- As with all gluten free baking--the baking time is increased up to 15 min...  
Bake until your desired doneness though--softer cookies less time, crunchier cookies longer

I made these after reading the reviews (good and bad) and they turned out great! You guys gave me ideas on how to tweak the recipe before hand, thank you. I used margarine, 2 eggs  (the 2nd one after mixing everything together because the dough was getting stiff), didn't add all the flour (used some of that when dealing with the dough with some sugar) and a tablespoon of peanut butter (just for fun). I also played with the heat and time. I believe that all recipes should be played with, especially when the reviews are mixed. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I halved the recipe. I used frozen butter, and microwaved it for thirty seconds on medium.  I used red food coloring to make this half red, and left the other half plain. I then took one pinch of red and one of white to marble it. They turned out BEAUTIFUL!!!!!! They taste wonderful, and melt in your mouth!!!!! This is the best cookie recipe EVER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Note: if you half this recipe, it is hard to use half an egg! But what did that worked pretty well was: first put your egg in an bowl. Then beat the egg. Then pour half into your batter. Wha-la!!!!!

I honestly don't eat sugar cookies but my husband loves them. When he arrived home I had a fresh batch ready. He loved them. 

This was a very simple recipe to make. My butter was frozen so I measured out the sugar and vanilla and placed butter in bowl and microwaved for 2 minutes. This made mixing much easier. After taking each set out of the oven I sprinkled some sugar and sprinkles.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1883754.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think this is a great, quick sugar cookie recipe with minimal change. I use two eggs and I bake them at 3 minutes and 45 seconds then rotate the pan and bake for another 3 minutes and 45 seconds. Granted all ovens are different but I found  this step and the added egg produces a very chewy cookie, that stays chewy for almost a week. Some tips I've found helpful 
- take the time to cream the sugar and butter so it's nice and fluffy.
- my teaspoon of baking soda is somewhere between heaping and level. 
-since i use the same pan between each bake cycle i wait till it cools completely before loading it up again. 
-i use a rounded measuring tablespoon when scooping the dough onto the pan. 
- i wait the full two minutes as instructed before removing the cookies from the pan.

city:

country:
None
text:
These were amazing! Probably the best sugar cookie recipe yet and soooooooo simple! After reading the reviews I did critique it a bit. I added 2 teaspoons of vanilla, instead of 1. After I blended everything together I did notice it was a bit crumbly like other reviewers mentioned so added another egg. So I used 2 eggs instead of one. That made them very fluffy and the dough was amazing! I couldn't stop eating it! Ha! Here are a few helpful tips as well. Make sure you used SALTED butter and it is completely softened. I kept them in for exactly 8 minutes and put them on a plate to cool. Any left overs put them in a tub-wear and place a piece of bread in there to keep them from hardening (a trick my mom taught me) and they will taste just as great the next day! Happy baking!

I've used many many many sugar cookie recipes and this is the easiest by far and if you refrigerate the dough for an hour or two then roll in a cinnamon sugar mix it makes the perfect snicker doodles! text:
The dough came out very crumbly, and I had made sure to follow the recipe EXACTLY. I was slightly wary, but since it wasn't exactly dry, just crumbly (if that makes any sense) I decided to roll with it. I put them in to oven and waited the directed amount of time. The cookies came out slightly small, like they didn't spread out all the way. I shrugged it off, since that didn't REALLY matter. What mattered was the taste. One of my brothers took a bite and told me they tasted fine, but the center wasn't cooked. So the next batch I decided to flatten the dough balls a little bit, to encourage them to take a better shape, and put them in for longer. Flattening the ball made them take the shape I wanted no problem. But putting them in for longer didn't fix my issue of the center not cooking:( The bottom just started to burn a bit but the inside stayed uncooked. I found it odd and tried a third time, with smaller dough balls. I figured that I was just putting too much dough down. Nope! still the same problem. I ate the cookies anyway, but I've had much better from equally as simple and quick recipes. the batter when uncooked taste AMAZING though. Absolutely amazing. Not the best but also not the worst

text:
Great sugar cookies - not fancy but tasty and easy to make.  I used butter but otherwise stuck to the recipe.  I then rolled in granulated sugar and pressed down with a glass to about 1/ 4 inch thick.  I baked the full amount of time and might even had added a couple minutes till were barely brown on the bottom.  I did not find them too hard when cooled.  These also kept well - put in a cookie jar they were still fresh about 5 days later (no kids around that week so they lasted longer than normal).  Excellent break snack with coffee too.

userID:
20206139
Display Name:
Sandy DeFoy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3806686.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic cookies! I have been looking for this type of sugar cookie recipe and thought I'd never find it! Easy and no refrigerating for an hour ahead. Crunchy texture on the outside but soft on inside. Pretty crackled top makes it look like its from a bakery. 

I did make a couple of changes to mine. First, I added 1/4 tsp of Princess flavoring. This added a mild citrus note to the cookies. Second, I dipped each cookie top in a sparkling white sugar. This really gave it a bakery look.  Third, 8 minutes made my cookies just a little undercooked. Watch your cookies closely. I went 8.5 minutes. Then turned the cookie sheet around in oven to get the front row a hint of brown.  Probably another 1/2 a minute . Once you see a touch of brown, take them out.  Make sure you use 1 rounded TBSP per cookie. No bigger! They will spread. Cool two minutes on the cookie sheet. Then remove to cool. I find placing mine on my counter top keeps them from having a rippled bottom.

This recipe makes a generous amount. I didn't have any problems of crumbly dough. Not sure why others would. Only problem I have is they are almost all gone! Everyone in the family told me "good cookies."  When they go for a glass a milk and plate of cookies, I know they're good !
Review:

userID:
20072963
Display Name:
Blaine

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3796464.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these because I was low on ingredients and these don't require much. I halved the recipe, used  2 1/2 tbsp margarine of my 1/2 cup butter. I let it get very soft and whipped it a little so it was smooth. I used about 3/4 of an egg in my halved recipe. Then added about 3/4 the flour, mix that then add the rest. The dough was nice, soft and a little tacky but very easy to work with after refrigerating for about 15 mins.
Definitely take these out exactly 8 mins for a chewy cookie. 
They were great. Soft, chewy inside, crisp outside. 
 Halved recipe made a little over two dozen cookies.

The dough should definitely not be crumbly.

text:
I made this a couple different times and have some tips from my own making of it.

I find that the amount of flour isn't quite enough. I use about 3 and 1/2 cups. It makes the batter much less sticky and much easier to form! Also, the dough feels soft and uncooked still at 8-10 minutes, but it's not raw still! Go ahead and take it out or it'll turn into a hockey puck!

Demo

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made these cookies several times and absolutely love them.  I just read the comments of the reviewer who said to use margarine and make sure it was soft like mush.  I've never used margarine and soften the butter up before using, often simply by microwaving 15 seconds, flipping the quarters onto an adjoining side, microwaving 10 seconds, flipping and microwaving 7 seconds...  I stop microwaving as soon as it begins to lose its firmness.  The fact that some of my fellow bakers have had difficulty with the dough and the cookie itself makes me wonder how many of them stop short of actually creaming the butter and sugar?  If  creamed sufficiently, the butter and sugar combine into a paste.  It no longer appears to be butter with sugar granules mixed in.  Stopping before this stage is reached would certainly affect both the consistency of the dough and the finished product.  This is a great recipe...simple and tasty...even without the fabulous and oh so easy recipe, Sugar Cookie Icing, found on this site.  But if you need a little more sweetness or want to make them appear finished, add icing.

2

text:
These were so easy. It was my first time making sugar cookies and they turned out so soft, chewy, and looked and tasted a lot like the ones you can buy from the store at the bakery for special occasions! Mine of course weren't iced butv they didn't need it! I actually put my sticks of butter in the microwave for about 30 sec to soften it. I also made my cookie balls into a golf ball size & sprayed my cookie sheet with cokking spray. They turned out perfect and my husband said they were the best sugar cookies he had ever had. We both agreed they were better then the pre-made Pillsbury dough. I even rolled my left over dough into a log and put it in the refrigerator.

userID:
18025754
Display Name:
njgin
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an awesome recipe.  I do not bake much during the year except at the holidays and this recipe was so easy.  I read a lot of the reviews beforehand and I made sure my butter was very soft, almost melted.  I softened it in the microwave on a low power setting.  I did not have an issue with consistency at all.  I also doubled the vanilla as others suggested.  These are probably the best sugar cookies I have ever eaten.  Also as others indicated, you need to be cognizant of the time in the oven.  I made them large and kept them in for 9 minutes.  If you are making them the normal size, I would not go past 8 minutes.  Delicious!!!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
The teaspoon sized balls gave me tiny little cookies so I rolled them twice as big, flattened them with the bottom of a glass and added pink sugar (for Easter).
I lowered the temp to 350 and baked for ten minutes making sure I used a cool pan each time. I also put the dough in the fridge for about 15 minutes.
They look perfectly cooked and taste fine.

This was one of the best sugar cookies I have ever had!the easiest and the best-tasting sugar cookie recipe i've tried.I was so surprised at how this was the easiest recipe ever and the best-tasting sugar cookie recipe i've tried. I think this is the best cookie if you add some "rock n roll" to it. thank you for this delicious recipe! my grandma and grandpa loved it for an easter gift if you decorate with some frosting you will come out with a easter-colorful-sugar-delicous-goey-cookie! With the stuff we put in our batter it wasn't as hard or gross as other reviews had described it! you should definitely try this recipe and if your feeling a little more work-ish then our twist to it is just right!

This is an awesome  sugar cookie recipe. I've made these cookies at least 4 times and everyone says they are the best they have ever had!  I did not change or add anything to the recipe. Once I roll the balls, I roll them lightly in some sugar on a plate (about 1/4 cup total). When I put them on the baking sheet, I flatten just a little with a glass. I did try to roll these out and did not have the best results. Make sure your butter is softened for best results! Thank you so much for posting!

text:
Loved it! I made only a slight change to the recipe...
I sifted the flour and added 1/2 tsp lemon extract to the dough. I rolled dough out onto a  lightly floured surface and cut out into heart shapes, etc. for Valentine's day. The dough does expand quite a bit during baking so the hearts and stuff didn't keep there shape very well. Before baking we sprinkled with colored sugar crystals. Next time I will stick to the suggested rolling of the dough into small round balls. The cookies were both soft and delicious! Easy recipe as stated and really good! I gave them a ten(on a scale of 1-10) My family rates new recipes for me all the time this way. My daughter gave it a 7. She said she thought it had too much sugar. =D Next time I won't add the sugar on top. It is best to stick to the recipe, lol! So good! Would make this again and again!

userID:
5797059
Display Name:
deerstalker
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
19
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe and the cookies came out perfect! I then read many of the reviews. I normally follow a new recipe the way it is written the first time before changing things around. This time I did make a few small deviations. I think the problem many people are having is measuring the flour. I use the measure conversation chart from Allrecipe and used the gram weights. I used my mixer and the wire whip attachment to cream the butter until it was light and fluffy. Then I added the sugar and whipped it some more before adding the egg and vanilla. I sifted my flour into a bowl on my scale set to grams. Added the baking powder and soda. Mixed the dry ingredients into the butter sugar egg vanilla mix with a large wooden spoon. I used a teaspoon to portion out the dough and rolled it easily into small balls, I ended up with 67. I like cinnamon so I rolled the balls into cinnamon sugar before baking. I baked them as directed 190C. for 10 minutes. Cooled them on the cookie sheet for 2 minutes then transferred them to a wire rack to finish cooling. I had no problems of cookies sticking or crumbling. To sum it up, it makes a great sugar cookie. Just a plain simple great sugar cookie. Looking for more use another recipe.

text:
My husband looooves sugar cookies! I make a killer chocolate chip cookie but due to his love for sugar cookies I did not think I could measure up. No so! These cookies were perfect! 
I made a few minor changes. I used completely melted Land O Lakes butter,  and 1 1/2 tspn of vanilla. As soon as they came out of the oven I sprinkled them with some organic cane sugar and they were delish! Try using Pam on your cookie sheet and baking for 12 min. 
I noticed some other reviews said that the cookies spread out too much. I did not have this problem. I used a tblspn scoop and put them about 3 in apart. They came out great! I hope this review helps. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Well, I'm not an expert baker or a connoisseur of sugar cookies. After reading the reviews, I decided to try these. They were easily made, chilled overnight, and the next day I attempted to roll them out which was-simply put-a disaster. The dough was impossible to roll. It was too dry and crumbly, even though I was very careful to follow the directions exactly. If I let the dough warm a bit, it was too sticky to roll. I ended up spooning them out as drop cookies. Then I used a glass dipped into sugar to squish them to the proper shape. They were delicious! I had tried rolling them out with sugar on my dough roller. That did not work, either. They are not extremely sweet as are the store cookies. I will try again. They are too delicious to give up! Happy baking!

the trick with these cookies, is after you roll them into balls, roll the balls in a bowl of sugar...then press them w/ a fork (like you would a PB cookie) then sprinkle on top w/ a colored sugar sprinkle. cook for 7 to 8 minutes..check at 7. they were perfectly soft, tasty, sugary,  DELISH!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The key is to let the butter sit out and get room temp before making. Don't microwave it to speed it up. Best sugar cookie I've ever eaten. I used the icing recipe that got really high reviews from this site as well. We let the dough set up in the fridge over night and baked them off the next morning. Rolled into 1" or so balls and they came out perfect. Once cooled, we just dipped the tops into the icing and used sprinkles to decorate. Once the icing was set, we covered the cookies. Cookies stayed moist until they were all eaten up. Will be making every year.

text:
These cookies are great. I live in a medical marijuana state, so I use my home made marijuana butter. A couple of points to make these come out perfect are: get some hot water from your tap and into a bowl, now float a smaller bowl in it, with your butter, and let it sit there til its melted. You need to experiment with size, its important with sugar cookies not to make them too small or they will be hard. Mine are perfect every time. I love this recipe. Maybe about an inch and a half for each cookie. make sure you take them out in 8 minutes !!

Stay-C

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thank you for sharing this recipe. My family really enjoyed it. I put a lemon twists in mine by adding approximately half a teaspoon of lemon extract to the batter, but I otherwise followed the recipe. I baked my cookies for 12 min and they ended up being on the crispy side. I will make this again adding a bit of salt and baking for less time to get a more chewy texture....UPDATE: I made it a second time with the following modifications:
(1) I rolled each cookie portion in a cinnamon/sugar mixture. 
(2) I added salt to the surface of the cookie
(3) No lemon extract this time. 
(4) I baked for 10 min instead of 12 min
The results were AMAZING. I highly recommend the salt addition. I used my salt mill to apply to the cookies, so it is difficult to articulate the precise amount that I used, but I am guessing it was approximately 1/4-1/2 tsp for the whole batch, which yielded 30 cookies, each approximately 2.5 inches in diameter. I tried adding the salt to the cinnamon/sugar mixture for part of my yield, but I liked the taste better when I sprinkled the salt directly on top of the pre-cooked cookie with my mill. UPDATE 2: I added 1 tsp grounded kosher salt to the dry ingredients before combining with the wet and baking with the cinnamon-sugar mixture on top...it was good, but I would cut the salt a bit next time by 1/3-1/2.

city:

country:
None
text:
These cookies came out delicious and perfect!  The only thing I did different was I used only 2 cups of flour because I ran out and adjusted the amount of baking soda and powder used to reflect the lessened amount of flour.  I guess that was a blessing in disguise as my dough didn't come out dry or crumbly like some said and the dough rolled into balls very easily.  I baked them at 375 as suggested and took them out at about 8 minutes and 30 seconds.  I found the extra 30 seconds really helped to bake the cookies thoroughly as the first test cookie I made at 8 minutes was still a tiny bit doughy.  They flattened out perfectly and will come out of the oven somewhat domed but as it cools, it flattens out more.  The only thing I will change for the next batch is to use a little bit less sugar as I like my cookies less sweet but otherwise this recipe will be used again :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not a sugar cookie fan, but these are really good. I ready through a number of reviews, including those saying their dough turned out crumbly. Here is what I'd recommend:
1. Measure your flour carefully! After the crumbly complaints, I sifted my flour and then gently spooned it into the measuring cups and leveled with a knife. I wonder if people may be packing in the flour a bit and adding density to the batter. I haven't noticed anyone make that recommendation yet, so that's probably my big contribution :)
2. I used margarine that was mostly room temperature - but I also beat it for quite a while for good measure. 
3. I used 2 teaspoons of vanilla (added a little extra moisture and flavor).
4. Finally, I did pull them out at about 7 minutes...at 8 minutes the bottoms started to get a bit more crispy.
I haven't served them to anyone yet - but I found them soft, a little crispy, and yummy. I'm sure they will go fast at Christmas.

text:
This recipe is crumbly--IF your egg is not large enough. I made it once and it was great. I made it again and it was dry and crumbly. The difference seems to be the egg size. The recipe calls for one, but use two if you're not using extra-large ones. You can also reduce the amount of flour by 1/4 cup to help compensate.

text:
AMAZING! Make sure to use soft butter (mine was out of the fridge so I stuck it in the microwave for about 20 seconds). I cooked them for 8 minutes like many suggested here in the reviews and they were soft & chewy inside. 
I added 1/2 tsp of almond extract in addition to 2 tsp of vanilla ... delicious!!
If you like thick chewy cookies then put them on the cookie sheet in balls, don't flatten the dough. They do spread while cooking, but not too much.
Enjoy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As is, this recipe rates a three. If you follow the suggestions made by others, it's a good sugar cookie with a buttery, just sweet enough flavor.  Though my alterations pretty much make this a different recipe,  here's what I'd recommend :

1. Use two (2) eggs instead of one.

2. Add 1/2 tsp kosher salt. (I use unsalted butter, so omit if you use salted butter or margarine.)

3. Increase vanilla extract to 1.5 tsp.

This is a drop cookie recipe and is not suitable for rolling and cutting. Also, my baking times ranged from 8-9 minutes and then I let the cookies cool on the parchment-lined cookie sheet.

text:
Originally, I had wanted a more easy sugar cookie for rolling out, but these seemed to be just quick and easy enough, and even though they are round, my kids could still decorate them with frosting. They have just the right consistency. Slightly crispy on the outside,  and chewy on the inside. I'm guessing you can make them rise more by putting in baking powder as well. But they are really fine as they were. The dough forms a ball better when it's cold, though. Otherwise, the dough gets slightly sticky.

I was looking for a quick way to make my first attempt at lavender cookies and stumbled across this recipe. I decided to use it as my base. I cut it in half, used 1/2 tsp vanilla, 1/2 tsp lemon extract, and added about 2tsps dried lavender. These came out not only delicious but like little heavenly pillows. text:
I really liked these. They were very easy to mix up. 8 minutes was perfect. I did try to roll some out between sheets of parchment paper sprinkled with powdered sugar. I also threw the dough in the freezer while a set baked before rolling them out. I did it pretty thick and liked the soft chewy texture. They are easy to decorate and even the few skinny ones that came out super crispy were delicious. I will be making these again and again.  I thought a teaspoon was a little too small for them, they baked to about the size of a quarter.  The larger rolled ones spread more.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've always been a terrible cookie maker so I wasn't expecting these to be any different. I read a lot of reviews and decided to have a go, adding two eggs instead of one and two tsps of vanilla extract. My butter was just a little firmer than room temperature since my house is on the cold side. I also had no baking soda so I added a couple more tea spoons of baking powder to compensate. Thanks to the awesome tips in the reviews, I also kneaded the dough with my hands, as it was definitely on the dry side, to bring the butter through and in about a minute I had the perfect consistency dough. 

I used a table spoon to spoon dough balls onto the baking trays, which I lined with foil, dull side up, then flattened down the balls a little with the back of the spoon and sprinkled a little sugar on top. I baked mine at 350 degrees for exactly 8 minutes and it was perfect in my oven. They were soft and looked undercooked but everyone had said that's how they should look so I resisted the urge to bake for longer and left them in the tray about five minutes before moving to the cooling rack. 

Of course a few may have accidentally fallen into my mouth before they'd completely firmed up and cooked but ahem...that happens, huh?  All I can say is they taste FANTASTIC and are nicely adaptable and even my husband who's not a sugar cookie lover, thought they were amazing. 

I got about 26 out of my batch. My only tip would be definitely knead the dough if it's dry and crumbly and it'll solve

I haven't finished cooking my cookies yet but MAKE SURE you use the right amount of each ingredients.This is VERY important to know.Also use sticks of butter because the people that brought my butter home, they brought the spreadable butter that didn't work so well.Also MAKE SURE that you use the right type of flour because i used a different type that i think made the cookies a bit wet.So after them being done, we had to throw away the cookies because they tasted so bad.So MAKE SURE you use the right butter because that is the key ingredient.

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this with a gluten free flour mix, added 1 tsp xantham gum, and they came out amazing! I followed someone else's suggestion to let the butter completely soften before making it. Since the temp appeared to be relevant, I went ahead and let the egg come to room temp as well while the butter was sitting out. From my childhood, I remember rolling the sugar cookie ball in sugar before baking, so I did that before cooking. I even tried cooking the cookies two different ways: I cooked them from balls and got softer, nicely domed cookies. I started out cooking these for my daughter's school Halloween party though, so for the class cookies, I flattened the balls with the bottom of a glass to get larger, flatter cookies. They both cooked perfect in the same amount of time. Finding a recipe that works so well with just substituting a gluten free flour in a normal recipe is such a pleasure!

Great, fool proof recipe.  I made them with my eight year old and they were great. We put sprinkles right in the dough to cut down on the mess, and they looked and tasted great. I will definitely make these again!

userID:
16208339
Display Name:
Brianna Flynn
isPro:

2

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2512868.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fast and simple and didn't really need chilling!

I subbed 1/2 cup corn syrup for 1/2 cup sugar, as I find this helps keep the cookies moist.

I added 1/2 tsp salt, because I find it always helps the flavor.

My cookies did not spread much at all, even with the addition of liquid sugar, so I can see using them for simple shapes (probably not anything complex like snowflakes, though.) I used plain old mostly softened butter, and it worked fine without needing it to be close to melted. Extra beating may help - I always beat my butter/sugar mixture until nearly all the butter color is gone. 

I use vanilla bean paste which is also a huge flavor booster - the kind that looks like dark brown sludge, not the syrupy kind from Williams Sonoma. 

These were topped with a vanilla buttercream icing, and are just fantastic!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-08-18T19:05:02.14
helpfulCount:
0

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I tried this recipe I mixed the dry and wet ingredients together in the same bowl, which was a BIG mistake. the batter turned into a crumbly mess, and I had to start over. Definitely  make sure you mix them separate before putting them together. Also make sure you soften the butter, not melt it. Melting the butter my second attempt caused the cookies to come out extremely thin and crispy, although they still had a nice flavor. Overall they were good cookies, but I would not recommend them to someone who wants a limited amount of work.

country:
None
text:
Added one more egg, half a teaspoon of vanilla and made sure that the butter is really really soft before I creamed it with sugar. 
The only problem I encountered was that it was hard to "shape" the dough, mine turned out sticky. Still, I managed to shape them by dusting my hands with a little bit of flour. Then I sprinkled honey granules and put a piece of chocolate chip on top of the cookies before baking. 

The cookies turned out to be perfect after 8 minutes. Soft yet a little crunchy on the outside - Buttery and creamy, not too sweet. :-) yum!

text:
My go-to sugar cookie recipe. I was looking for a recipe one day, out of boredom, and I saw this one. The reviews are all so positive and the cookies themselves seemed more than worth a try. I made them and my entire family fell in love. They began constantly begging me to make more, and I was always so excited to. I've experimented with different icings and frosting, with bake time, and with different colors. I have found what is, in my opinion, the best time to let them bake, and I'm very pleased. They aren't too soft, and they aren't too firm either- they're just right, and they're addicting. To the creator of this recipe; Bravo.

text:
Very easy to make! The dough is easy to work with (I used cookie cutters and the dough wouldn't crumble and would roll out perfectly). My only complaint would be that the serving sizes are way off. I changed the serving size to 12, and the dough wasn't even enough to feed 5 hungry cookie eaters. So I would suggest you'd make way more than the serving size tells you how many people this will feed. Otherwise, these cookies came out well. Although, I kept them in the oven a tad longer than the bake time that was said. Then they were ready to come out of the oven.

text:
Followed recipe exactly except I used 2 tsp. of vanilla. Made sure the butter was completely softened before creaming as someone else suggested. At first I thought the batter was too crumbly but the heat and pressure of your hands,as you roll the dough into balls,knits it together nicely. I used a rounded measuring tsp. and wound up with 70 cookies! I dipped each ball into colored sugar and baked for 10 minutes. Each cookie was approx. 2 inches in diameter when done. Absolutely delicious and slightly chewy, highly recommended! I will use these as part of my Chritmas gift trays for friends. Happy Holidays! John

This is a good simple recipe.  It was missing salt so i added 1/2 a tsp.  I was also wanting a christmas cookie that was easier than biscotti so i added dried crandberries and candied orange to the sugar and pulverized it in a food processor.  I also added orange extract.  It was a perfect texture with a holiday flavor.  I also melted white chocolate and drizzled it accross the top.  I will use this base recipe again.

Display Name:

isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wanted an easy Christmas cookie recipe without a lot of mess or fuss, so of course the word "easy" in the title caught my eye. After reading many of the reviews and hints -- one mentioned that the butter should be extra soft -- I made these. Oh. My. Heck. Easy is right! And my family can't stop eating them! Soft, chewy, with just the right bit of crisp around the edges, and not too sweet. When I tried to soften my butter in the microwave, it totally melted, so I added the sugar anyway, then put the bowl in the fridge for 10 minutes. And contrary to what someone else posted, these don't spread out that far on the cookie sheet. No one in our family likes iced cookies, so these are just perfect for us. Highly recommend! Highly!

text:
I read through all of the reviews and was surprised that more people did not experience how crumbly this dough is. I made sure that my butter was room temp beffort I started to cream the egg and vanilla with it. The dough was so crumbly that I couldn't even get it to hold together. Too much flour. I ended up adding another egg and 2 tbls of butter. This gave me a workable dough. I am not impressed with the overall taste.  They are very bland. I whipped up some buttercream frosting to top them and make them sweeter. Overall I don't think I'll try this recipe again. I will stick to a classic sugar cook recipe from now on.

text:
Nice recipe. Five stars because it did exactly what was described, so no surprises, the result was exactly what I was looking for,and no changes were needed. 

I made it exactly as is. Icelandic butter is a little stickier than American butter, so this still needed to be chilled a bit to be rolled. Watch the baking time really carefully. If you want them to stay soft then take them out the moment the edges start to brown.

Display Name:
Jess Jess

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! Giving this a 4 star instead of 5 because I did a lot to the recipe to make it more awesome. First, I cut the recipe in half. (I didn't want to make 4 dozen, only 2) I kept the egg and vanilla amounts as the original recipe because so many people complained of a hard crumbly dough (eggs tenderize pastries) and that the recipe was tasteless (vanilla extract helps with flavor). I then let the butter completely soften (letting it melt on the stove is a bad idea. Melted butter can melt the sugar. This is bad because sugar is also a tenderizer for the flour.) Then I went about my business as the recipe directed, mixing REALLY well. I molded the cookies into flatten balls. I didn't place them on a greases cookie sheet, but parchment paper over a cookie sheet. Parchment paper is the BEST! As a finishing touch, I sprinkled sugar over the cookies. I cooked both batches for 8 minutes as the recipe said and let them rest on the cookie sheet for 2 minutes. They come out so tender and crispy and soft and tasty! YUM YUM YUM!!!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2014-11-30T13:16:56.56

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Considering that I have NEVER made cookies from scratch, I found this recipe extremely easy and the cookies turned out great. I read through the reviews beforehand, so I ended up only increasing the vanilla extract to 2 tsp. At first I was worried that the dough would turn out crumbly as other reviewers had stated, and when I first began to add the flour mixture to the butter and sugar I thought it was going to turn out awful. I kept mixing the dough and after a few minutes it came together perfectly. I baked them for the recommended 8 minutes and the cookies came out soft and chewy. I love sugar cookies, but I found that these did taste a bit like flour. I think next time I'll try adding some lemon to them.

text:
A refreshing cookie. Better than store-bought. Here are the changes I made- used only one cup of sugar and added one and a half teaspoons of Orange Blossom water. I also only cooked the cookies for nine minutes in the oven. I live in Denver Colorado so  up here things cook quicker. My cookies were perfectly soft and were not crumbly like many other reviewers reported. Do not over cook these cookies and you will be fine!

I was looking for an easy sugar cookie recipe that made a good cookie.  What I found was that this recipe makes an easy great cookie!!  I can't figure out how some of the people who wrote the reviews had bad luck with this recipe.  I will say, that my butter had sat out for hours so it was very soft (not melted).  My grandson and I made these and they came out perfect first time.  I have made them since and they always come out perfect.  Looking forward to making them at Christmas with green and red sprinkles.  Also, looking forward to making them with lemon flavoring. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading some of the reviews I baked the cookies for 8 minutes. Instead of using the "stick butter" I used butter that comes in the plastic tubs, like country crock. It's already soft for the most part. It is really important to gradually mix in the dry ingredients, so don't get ahead of yourself. As long as the cookies are baked no more than 8 minutes they come out perfect and taste amazing! Also try different flavored extracts in lieu of vanilla, like rum or peppermint for the holidays.

This is the BEST sugar cookie recipe! I actually used the dough for shape cookies for Halloween so I put the dough in the fridge for an hour. city:

country:
None
text:
A really great sugar cookie recipe! Like another poster had put it, I too was looking for a good sugar cookie recipe. I've tried so many and they would most of the time be way too thick or just as flat as a pancake no matter what i tried. I would like to add that I used margarine for this recipe (country crock) and it turned out just fine. I also just plopped the dough onto the sheet rather than roll it and it made the pretty cracks in the cookie. I tried rolling the dough and giving it the tiniest pat and they didn't turn out as good looking so I suggest stick with the plopping, haha. I made half the batch plain for the kids and the other half snickerdoodles. I'm going to add my picture of the snickerdoodles so keep and eye out for it ;) This was a nice, light, not-too-sweet cookie and I had the dough made and on the cookie sheet before the pre-heat oven beeper went off, lol! Give it a try!!!

text:
These cookies were pretty good. With such basic ingredients, I was able to bake my first cookie from scratch--That is without grandma. I followed the recipe exactly as stated except for I replaced the egg with a mixture of 2 tablespoons of water, 1 teaspoon of oil and 2 teaspoons of baking powder and I added an additional 1/2 teaspoon of vanilla. This worked great with this recipe. I wish I had seen the post stating to take them out of the oven at 8 minutes, no longer. They are a bit crisp, but not falling apart. They're still a good chewy, yummy cookie. Simple and awesome!

text:
I love this recipe. Half way through mixing the dry and wet ingredients the dough got crumbly. Once it was done, however, I chilled it for two hours and dropped teaspoons of them on the baking sheet. My oh my are they good. And heres a tip. If yiu are just getting your butter out of the fridge, run it in the microwave for about 20 seconds.  The inside will melt but the outside will be only slightly warm and that means the sugar will cream into it better.and dont be tempted to do shapes with this recipe.  I tryed and the teapots and teacups I made look like blobs. Yummy, roundish, slightly warm blobs. I also added half a teaspoon of salt to give it a kick in the right place.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very easy, took the suggestion of adding more vanilla (I did an addtl. 1 tsp but 1/2 would be sufficient), room temperature butter, and baking for 8 minutes and they came out great. I mixed everything with a hand mixer and it looked crumbly, until I rolled them for the baking sheet - they were perfect! I rolled some in sugar and they came out that delicate white with those sugar sparkles. Beautiful! I also rolled some in sugar and cinnamon and the very last bit I added a little nutmeg into the mix as well. All seem to be popular with my husband who is picky about his cookies!

They flattened a little bit (see photo) but relatively held their shape. I could see these working for cookie cutters!

8 minutes is perfect, they look soft but harden just enough once out of the oven. One batch I left in an extra minute or so and they were a firmer (and a bit dryer) overall.

text:
Awesome!!  I used the "change servings" option to make only 12 cookies.  It asked for 1/4 of an egg.  Even though I was not very accurate with measuring the egg, plus adding food coloring and extra flour to make up for the added liquid, these still worked.  I added extra vanilla for flavor also.  They tasted great and had a nice texture.  I read another review that said to make sure the butter was completely softened so I made sure to do that as well.  Will definitely make these again.  Very easy and not very many ingredients!

text:
Great cookies! They are still delicious and chewy two days later. I knew the day before that I wanted to bake these cookies the next say so my butter (unsalted) sat for a full day on counter top. I realized that I'd ran out of baking powder so I used 2 tsps of baking soda and a tsp of fresh lemon  juice to make up for those acidic components and they were absolutely out of this world! I did start with rounded tsps of dough but they were too small. So I finished up with 1/2tbsp for each cookie. 1tsp will take 8mins and the 1/2tbsp took no more than 10mins. Enjoy!

text:
This was a basic "good to ramp up" type of recipe. Like others, I softened the butter, to the point that I put it in the microwave for 15 seconds. I used almond extract and doubled the amount. I then stuck with 8 minutes as others did.

The one place the recipe went wrong was putting them on an ungreased cookie sheet. They stuck to the pan, big time, and the only way I was able to bake the second batch was to put a piece of waxed paper over the stuck-on bits and layering the cookies from there. 

Overall, just OK. Nothing special.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
NEEDS TWEEKING!!!!   I made this recipe twice.  First time I followed the directions exactly as written.  The dough was too dry and the cookies came out hard. Second time:  I cut the flour in half and kept the wet ingredients as written.  Cookies came out perfect and delicious.  My kids loved them.  I loved them.  I ate too many of them.  If you are going to do this recipe please watch the dry ingredients.  Add them slowly and stop when the dough becomes firm enough to make balls easily with your fingers.  Too much flour can cause an unhappy cookie.  In the future I will be using only half the dry ingredients due to my most recent experience.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-02-05T14:29:27.303

I use this recipe all the time. It's one of the few recipes that I change. The butter being crumbly is never an issue for me since I always have a stick or two at room temp. This recipe is also perfect for making snickerdoodles. Just roll each ball in a mixture of equal parts cinnamon and sugar. userID:
12439354
Display Name:
maliboo_barbie
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The dough was crumbly as some people said--but the cookies weren't dry.  In fact, I had to lower the oven and bake them not a second longer than 8 minutes.  The bottoms were overbrowned and the insides were still a touch squishy.  Not ideal results.  I did soften the butter in the microwave on the lowest setting, bcs of the house not being warm enough to achieve soft butter at room temperature.  That being said, the cookies still firmed up when cool and are just not at all what I expected from other people's experiences with this recipe!  I tried to save these with icing in them, macaron-style.  The cookies are too firm, though, and the icing squishes out.  I tried making the balls of dough larger and flattening them with a pancake turner a bit before baking.  Those did spread out and look more normal, but they really got too brown and I was a little horrified.  My roommate thought they were the best she'd ever eaten in her entire life.  (I won't tell you how old she is, but that's a good compliment. LOL)  I felt like everything went wrong with this recipe, but it wasn't for lack of trying. I should have gone through the trouble of making a rolled-dough style cookie batch, instead.  I'm not making this again. Sad face.

ACTUALY, thre and a 1/2 . one batch yeilded .35 cookyz. I made them for a moUse party. My second cousin is allergic to flour but he was ok. We used colored suger, It made them look EXTRA-ordinary  . I used fun cookie cutters, like butterflys, dinosaurs, firetrucks, the number five, hearts, ducs, shooting star/ A+ medal, etc. The truck didn't turn out very well. I recommmend using about 5and a 1/2 more Eggs, but just the whites and yolks. not the shells. Also, it doesn't tell you this, but you should stir with a spoon, not your hands. I learnd the hard Way-- my first batch came out too lumpie and more was on my HANDs, you know. So, in conclusion, this is a god recipie that makes about 458.59 cookyz. Good for ppl allergic to flour. They dont react.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies turned out great, but only after some tweaking of the recipe.  After adding and mixing the dry ingredients, the dough became very crumbly - too crumbly to form into balls.  I had even done as other reviewers said and made sure my butter was completely softened by letting it sit out for a few hours.  I am an amateur baker so I am unsure if my fix was the "correct" way to do things, but I added some milk a tiny bit at a time until the dough was of a better consistency, and they turned out very well after exactly 8 minutes in the oven.  Slightly crisp on the outside, chewy but not gooey on the inside.  I made them for Christmas and rolled them in colored sugar before baking.

text:
I used the advice of other reviews - microwaved butter for 35 seconds, added an additional egg & 1/2 tsp vanilla.   Dough was very creamy.  I just kept stirring.  I can see what people were saying about floury dough, but if you keep mixing it gets better.   Make 50 or so cookies which we decorated differently.  I cooked them for 7 minutes.  I made the M&M cookies a bit bigger & inserted the candy with 2 minutes left to cook.  Will definitely make again!

text:
The reason the cookies spread so much is because of the amount of sugar. The more sugar you use the more they will spread . The less sugar use the they wont sspread as much so if you want a cookie that doesn't spread as much, instead of putting 1 1/2 c. Sugar use just 1cup. Other than that its a good formula

text:
I give this recipe 5 stars.  I am gluten free, so I added a little less than 1/4th cup EXTRA gf flour per cup of flour.  You can add a few drops of water to get the consistency right.  I also add 1/2 tsp almond extract on top of the vanilla extract, to the recipe because I like the almond taste.  When gf, you add around 3/4 tsp. xanthan gum for each cup of flour for elasticity.  Great recipe!!

Pretty good recipe for an easy sugar cookie. I followed the recipe exactly since I'm not the best at improvisation and they were okay. You really have to make substitutions with this. They came out great! I, however, would not have enjoyed them as the recipe was written...a little dry...but overall, as I said, a great base for additional ingredients. Thanks for sharing!

text:
The only thing that I didn’t like about this recipe was that I had to add another egg because the batter was starting to come out dry. Any cookie recipe I’ve ever used always called for two large eggs, not just one. This is the second recipe this week that I had to adjust and add another egg instead of just the one that these dry recipes call for.

I always use salted butter due to the fact that I never add actual salt to anything that I bake. Every other ingredient I followed exactly. I did have to shorten the baking time. First, I did 6 minutes. They came out really good, the only flaw was that the bottoms were a little on the crunchy side. Therefore, I adjusted them to 5 minutes and they came out perfect! They’re just sweet enough to satisfy and they have that delicious buttery taste that I love! Hence why I use butter! Well, aside from that one soy allergy I have.

text:
Great sugar cookie recipe!!!
Only cook 8 minutes as suggested by other users unless you like them crispy...if you have a newer oven or a one that typically over cooks I would only do 7.  
I would also add a little more vanilla extra and put in the refrigerator for literally maybe 10 or 15  minutes..just helps the cookies ball up a little easier, oh and roll them in sugar for an extra yummy touch.

Display Name:
Kristen Luckett
